\(\int \sqrt{4 x -3} dx\) 

As we know,

\(\int x ^{ n } dx =\frac{ x ^{ n +1}}{ n +1}+ c\)

\(I=\int \sqrt{4 x-3} d x\)

Let \(4 x-3=t^2 \quad \ldots \) (1)

Differenating with respect to \(x\), we get

\(\Rightarrow 4 d x=2 t d t\)

\(\Rightarrow d x=\frac{t}{2} d t\)

Now,

\(I =\int \sqrt{ t ^2} \times \frac{ t }{2} dt\)

\(=\frac{1}{2} \int t ^2 dt\)

\(=\frac{ t ^3}{6}+ c\)

Putting the value of 't' from equation (1)

\(=\frac{(4 x -3)^{\frac{3} {2}}}{6}+ c\)

Given:

\(\int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{1}{1+\tan ^3 x} d x\)

We know that,

\(\int_a^b f(x) d x=\int_a^b f(a+b-x) d x\)

According to the question,

\(\int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{1}{1+\tan ^3 x} d x=\int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{1}{1+\tan ^3\left(\frac{\pi}{3}+\frac{\pi}{6}-x\right)} d x\)

\(\Rightarrow \int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{1}{1+\tan ^3 x} d x=\int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{1}{1+\tan ^3\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-x\right)} d x\)

\(\Rightarrow \int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{1}{1+\tan ^3 x} d x=\int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{1}{1+\cot ^3 x} d x\)

\(\Rightarrow \int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{1}{1+\tan ^3 x} d x=\int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{1}{1+\frac{\cos ^3 x}{\sin ^3 x}} d x\)

\(\Rightarrow \int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{1}{1+\tan ^3 x} d x=\int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{\sin ^3 x}{\sin ^3 x+\cos ^3 x} d x \quad \ldots \ldots\) (1)

Now, As per the question,

\(\int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{1}{1+\tan ^3 x} d x=\int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{1}{1+\frac{\sin ^3 x}{\cos ^3 x}} d x \quad \quad \) As we know \(\tan x=\frac{\sin x}{\cos x}\)

\(\Rightarrow \int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{1}{1+\tan ^3 x} d x=\int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{\cos ^3 x}{\cos ^3 x+\sin ^3 x} d x \quad \ldots \ldots\) (2)

Adding equation 1 and equation 2,

\(2 \int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{1}{1+\tan ^3 x} d x=\int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{\sin ^3 x+\cos ^3 x}{\sin ^3 x+\cos ^3 x} d x\)

\(\Rightarrow 2 \int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{1}{1+\tan ^3 x} d x=\int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} d x\)

\(\Rightarrow 2 \int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{1}{1+\tan ^3 x} d x=\left[\frac{\pi}{3}-\frac{\pi}{6}\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow 2 \int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{1}{1+\tan ^3 x} d x=\frac{\pi}{6}\)

\(\Rightarrow \int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{1}{1+\tan ^3 x} d x=\frac{\pi}{12}\)

According to the question:
Here we have to find the value of \(\int \frac{d x}{e^{x}-1}\)
Let \(e^{x}=t\) and by differentiating \(e^{x}=t\) with respect to \(x\) we get
\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{x}} \mathrm{dx}=\mathrm{dt}\) or \(\mathrm{dx}=\mathrm{dt} / \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{x}}=\mathrm{dt} / \mathrm{t}\)
\(\Rightarrow \int \frac{d x}{e^{x}-1}=\int \frac{d t}{t(t-1)}\)
Let \(\frac{1}{t(t-1)}=\frac{A}{t}+\frac{B}{t-1}\)
\(\Rightarrow 1=A(t-1)+B t \ldots(1)\)
By putting \(t=0\) on both the sides of (1) we get \(A=-1\)
By putting \(t=1\) on both the sides of (1) we get \(B=1\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{t(t-1)}=\frac{-1}{t}+\frac{1}{t-1}\)
\(\Rightarrow \int \frac{d t}{t(t-1)}=-\int \frac{d t}{t}+\int \frac{d t}{t-1}\)
As we know that \(\int \frac{d x}{x}=\log |x|+C\) where \(C\) is a constant
\(\Rightarrow \int \frac{d t}{t(t-1)}=-\log |t|+\log |t-1|+C\)
\(=\log \left|\frac{t-1}{t}\right|+C\)
By substituting \(e^{x}=t\) in the above equation we get
\(\Rightarrow \int \frac{d x}{e^{x}-1}=\log \left|\frac{e^{x}-1}{e^{x}}\right|+C\)

If the area of the region bounded by \(y=\cos x, y=\sin x, x=\frac{\pi}{4}\) and \(x=\pi\) is bisected by the line \(x = a\), then \(\sin \left( a +\frac{\pi}{4}\right)=\)

Plotting the curves we get:

According to the question, the area is bisected by the line \(x=a\)

\(\Rightarrow \int_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^a(\sin x-\cos x) d x=\int_a^\pi(\sin x-\cos x) d x \)

\(\Rightarrow[-\cos x-\sin x]_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^a=[-\cos x-\sin x]_a^\pi \)

\(\Rightarrow(-\cos a-\sin a)-\left(-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)=(1)-(-\cos a-\sin a) \)

\(\Rightarrow-\cos a-\sin a+\sqrt{2}=1+\cos a+\sin a \)

\(\Rightarrow 2(\sin a+\cos a)=\sqrt{2}-1 \)

\(\Rightarrow \sin a+\cos a=\frac{\sqrt{2}-1}{2} \ldots(\text { i })\)

Now, \(\sin \left( a +\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\)

\(=\sin a \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}+\cos a \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \)

\(=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\sin a +\cos a ) \)

\(=\frac{\sqrt{2}-1}{2 \sqrt{2}}[\text { using (i)] }\)
What is the area of the region bounded by \(x-|y|=0\) and \(x-2=0\)?

Curve \(x-|y|=0\) and \(x-2=0\)


The area of the region bounded by the curve is

\(=\int_{x=0}^{x=2} \int_{y=-x}^{y=x} d y d x \)

\(=\int_{x=0}^{x=2} x-(-x) d x \)

\(=\int_{x=0}^{x=2} 2 x d x \)

\(=2 \int_{x=0}^{x=2} x d x \)

\(=2 \times\left[\frac{x^2}{2}\right]_{x=0}^{x=2} \)

\(=2 \times \frac{4}{2} \)

\(=4\)
The area of the loop of the curve \(a y^2=x^2(a-x)\) is equal to:

We have,

\(\Rightarrow ay ^2= x ^2( a - x ) \)

\(\text { At } x =0, y =0 \)

\(\text { At } x = a , y =0 \)

\(\Rightarrow y ^2=x^2\left(\frac{a-x}{a}\right) \)

\(\Rightarrow y =x\left(\sqrt{\frac{a-x}{a}}\right)\)

The total area of the loop is \(A=2 A_1\) where

\(\Rightarrow A _1=\int_{x=0}^a \frac{1}{\sqrt{a}} x \sqrt{a-x} d x\)

Let \(a - x = z ^2\)

\(\Rightarrow dx =-2 zdz \)

\(\Rightarrow At x =0, z =\sqrt{a}\)

At \(x = a , z =0\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{\sqrt{a}} \int_{\sqrt{a}}^0 z\left(a-z^2\right)(-2 z d z) \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{2}{\sqrt{a}} \int_0^{\sqrt{a}} z^2\left(a-z^2\right) d z\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{2}{\sqrt{a}}\left[\frac{z^3 a}{3}-\frac{z^5}{5}\right]_0^{\sqrt{a}} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{2}{\sqrt{a}}\left(\frac{a^2 \sqrt{a}}{3}-\frac{a^2 \sqrt{a}}{5}\right) \)

\(\Rightarrow 2\left(\frac{a^2}{3}-\frac{a^2}{5}\right) \)

\(\Rightarrow 2\left(\frac{5 a^2-3 a^2}{15}\right) \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{4 a^2}{15}\)

Total area \(=2 A _1=\frac{8 a^2}{15}\)

\(\therefore\) The area of the loop of the curve ay \({ }^2 x^2(a-x)\) is equal to \(\frac{8 a^2}{15}\).
The area in the first quadrant between \(x^2+y^2=\pi^2\) and \(y=\sin x\) is:

\(x^2+y^2=\pi^2 \)

\(y=\sin x\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Required Area \(=\frac{\pi \cdot \pi^2}{4}-[-\cos x]_0^\pi\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Required Area \(=\frac{\pi^3}{4}+(\cos \pi-\cos 0)\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Required Area \(=\frac{\pi^3}{4}+(-1-1)\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Required Area \(=\frac{\pi^3}{4}-2\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Required Area \(=\frac{\pi^3-8}{4}\) sq. units

\(\therefore\) The required area is \(\frac{\pi^3-8}{4}\) sq. units.
The area bounded by the parabola \(y^2=4 x\) and the latus rectum is:

As we know,

\(y^2=4 a x\) is the standard form of parabola \(4 a=\) length of latus rectum.

Now,

Here, \(y^2=4 b x\)

Comparing standard equation of parabola,

\(4 b x=4 a x \)

\(\therefore a=b\)


Now, Area enclosed by parabola and its latus rectum

\(=2 \int_0^b ydx \)

\(=2 \int_0^b 2 \sqrt{ bx } dx \)

\(=4 \sqrt{ b} \left[\frac{2}{3} x ^{\frac{3 }{ 2}}\right]_0^{ b } \)

\(=4 \sqrt{ b}\times \frac{2}{3} b ^{\frac{3 }{ 2}} \)

\(=\frac{8}{3} b ^2 \)

Hence, For the given parabola \(y ^2=4 x ,( b =1)\), Area enclosed by parabola and its latus rectum is \(\frac{8}{3}\) square units.
What is the area included in the first quadrant between the curves \(y=x\) and \(y=x^3\)?

Given:

The line \(y=x\) lies above the curve \(y=x^3\) in the first quadrant and \(y=x^3\) lies above the line \(y=x\) in the third quadrant.

Solve the curves to obtain the point of intersection \(y=x^3, y=x \Rightarrow x^3=x\).

Equating the values of \(y\), we get,

\(\Rightarrow x=x^3 \)

\(\therefore x^3-x=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow x\left(x^2-1\right)=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow x(x-1)(x+1)=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow x=\{0, \pm 1\}\)


Required area in the first quadrant, \(A =\int_0^x\left(x-x^3\right) d x\)

\(\Rightarrow A =\int_0^1 x d x-\int_0^1 x^3 d x \)

\(\Rightarrow A =\left[\frac{x^2}{2}-\frac{x^4}{4}\right]_0^1 \)

\(\Rightarrow A =\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{4}\right)-(0-0) \)

\(\Rightarrow A =\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{4}=\frac{1}{4}\)

\(\therefore\) The area included in the first quadrant between the curves \(y = x\) and \(y = x ^3\) is \(\frac{1}{4}\) square units.
Area of the region in the first quadrant enclosed by the \(x\)-axis, the line \(y=x\) and the circle \(x^2+y^2=32\) is:

Given the \(x\)-axis, the line \(y=x\) and the circle \(x^2+y^2=32\).

By substitution;

\(\Rightarrow x^2+x^2=32 \)

\(\Rightarrow x=4\)

Radius of the circle \(=\sqrt{32}=4 \sqrt{ 2}\)

\(\therefore\) Required area:

\(A=\int_0^4 x d x+\int_4^{4 \sqrt{2}}\left(\sqrt{32-x^2}\right) d x\left[\because \int \sqrt{a^2-x^2} d x=\frac{x \sqrt{a^2-x^2}}{2}+\frac{a^2}{2} \sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{x}{a}\right)\right] \)

\(=\int_0^4 x d x+\int_4^{4 \sqrt{2}}\left(\sqrt{(4 \sqrt{2})^2-x^2}\right) d x \)

\(=\left[\frac{x^2}{2}\right]_0^4+\left[\frac{ x \sqrt{(4 \sqrt{2})^2-x^2}}{2}+\frac{(4 \sqrt{2})^2}{2} \sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{ x }{4 \sqrt{2}}\right)\right]_4^{4 \sqrt{2}} \)

\(=\left((8-0)+\left(\frac{32}{2} \times \frac{\pi}{2}\right)-\frac{16}{2}-\left(\frac{32}{2} \times \frac{\pi}{4}\right)\right) \)

\(=(8+8 \pi-8-4 \pi) \)

\(=4 \pi\)

\(\therefore\) The area of the region in the first quadrant enclosed by the \(x\)-axis, the line \(y = x\) and the circle \(x ^2+ y ^2=32\) is \(4 \pi\) sq units.
The area enclosed by the ellipse \(\frac{x^2}{a^2}+\frac{y^2}{b^2}=1\) is equal to:

We have the equation of ellipse \(\frac{ x ^2}{ a ^2}+\frac{ y ^2}{ b ^2}=1\).

The area of the ellipse is four times the area of the first quadrant. For the region of interest, the limits of integration are \(x=0\) and \(x=a\).

\(\therefore \frac{ x ^2}{ a ^2}+\frac{ y ^2}{ b ^2}=1 \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{ y ^2}{ b ^2}=1-\frac{ x ^2}{ a ^2} \)

\(\Rightarrow y ^2= b ^2\left(\frac{ a ^2- x ^2}{ a ^2}\right) \)

\(\Rightarrow y =\sqrt{ b ^2\left(\frac{ a ^2- x ^2}{ a ^2}\right)} \)

\(\Rightarrow y = \pm \frac{ b }{ a } \sqrt{ a ^2- x ^2} \)

\(\Rightarrow y =\frac{ b }{ a } \sqrt{ a ^2- x ^2}[\because y >0 \) in the first quadrant ]

\(\therefore\) Required area:

\(A =4 \int_0^{ a } ydx \)

\(=4 \int_0^{ a } \frac{ b }{ a } \sqrt{ a ^2- x ^2} \)

\(=\frac{4 b}{a}\left[\frac{x \sqrt{a^2-x^2}}{2}+\frac{a^2}{2} \sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{x}{a}\right)\right]_0^a \)

\(=\frac{4 b}{a}\left[\left(0+\frac{a^2}{2} \cdot \frac{\pi}{2}\right)-0\right] \)

\(= \pi аb\) sq units

Therefore, the area enclosed by the ellipse \(\frac{x^2}{a^2}+\frac{y^2}{b^2}=1\) is \(\pi ab\) sq units.
The area of the region bounded by the curve \(y=\sqrt{16-x^2}\) and \(x\)-axis is:

\(\therefore\) The required area is given by:

\(A = \)

\(\int_{-4}^4\left(\sqrt{16-x^2}\right) d x\left[\because \int \sqrt{a^2-x^2} d x=\frac{x \sqrt{a^2-x^2}}{2}+\frac{a^2}{2} \sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{x}{a}\right)\right] \)

\(=2 \int_0^4\left(\sqrt{4^2-x^2}\right) d x \)

\(=2\left[\frac{x \sqrt{4^2-x^2}}{2}+\frac{4^2}{2} \sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{x}{4}\right)\right]_0^4 \)

\(=2\left(0+\frac{8 \pi}{2}-0-0\right) \)

\(=8 \pi \) sq units. 

\(\therefore\) The area of the region bounded by the curve \(y =\sqrt{16- x ^2}\) and the \(x\)-axis is \(8 \pi\) sq units.
The area of the region bounded by the curve \(x^2=4 y\) and the straight line \(x=4 y-2\) is:

Given, curve \(x^2=4 y\) and the straight line \(x=4 y-2\)

Substituting \(y=\frac{x^2}{4}\)

\(\Rightarrow x =4\left(\frac{x^2}{4}\right)-2 \)

\(\Rightarrow x = x ^2-2 \)

\(\Rightarrow x ^2- x -2=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow( x -2)( x +1)=0 \)

\(=\frac{1}{4}\left[\frac{x^2}{2}+2 x-\frac{x^3}{3}\right]_{-1}^2 \)

\(=\frac{1}{4}\left[6+\frac{3}{2}\right]-\frac{1}{12}[9] \)

\(=\frac{1}{4} \times \frac{15}{2}-\frac{3}{4} \)

\(=\frac{15}{8}-\frac{3}{4} \)

\(=\frac{9}{8} \) sq units.

The area bounded by curve \(y=x|x|, x\) axes and ordinates \(x=1, x=-1\) is given by:

Area \(=\left|\int_{-1}^1 x\right| x|d x|=\left|\int_{-1}^0 x\right| x|d x|+\left|\int_0^1 x\right| x|d x| \)

\( =\left|\int_{-1}^0 x(-x) d x\right|+\left|\int_0^1 x \cdot x d x\right|=\left|\int_{-1}^0-x^2 d x\right|+\left|\int_0^1 x^2 d x\right| \)

\( =\left[\frac{-x^3}{3}\right]_{-1}^0+\left[\frac{x^3}{3}\right]_0^1=\frac{2}{3}\)
The area of the region : \(R=\left\{(x, y): 5 x^2 \leq y \leq 2 x^2+9\right\}\) is:

Given that to find an area of a region between \(5 x^2\) and \(2 x^2+9\) for that draw \(y=5 x^2\) and \(y=2 x^2+9\).


For the Required area subtract the equation of the larger region and smaller region to get a region enclosed by both of them, also noticed that regions on both sides of the y-axis are mirror images of each other so twice the region of the positive side of \(x\)-axis from 0 to \(\sqrt{ 3}\) add as limit of \(x\) variable in integral.

\(=2 \int_0^{\sqrt{ 3}}\left(2 x^2+9-5 x^2\right) d x \)

\(=2 \int_0^{\sqrt{ } 3}\left(9-3 x^2\right) d x \)

Hence the area of the region enclosed by the given equations is \(12 \sqrt{ 3}\).
The slope of tangent to curve \(y=f(x)\) at \([x, f(x)]\) is \(2 x+1\). If the curve passes through the point \((1,2)\), then the area bounded by the curve, the \(x\)-axis and the line \(x=1\), is:

Given,

The slope of tangent to curve \(y=f(x)\) at \([x, f(x)]\) is \(2 x+1\).

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d y}{d x}=2 x +1\)

Integrating both sides with respect to \(x\),

\(\Rightarrow y=\int(2 x+1) d x \)

\(\Rightarrow y=x^2+x+c\)

Since the curve passes through the point \((1,2)\)

\(\Rightarrow 2=1^2+1+c \)

\(\Rightarrow c=0\)

So, the curve is given by \(f(x)=x^2+x\)

As the curve passes through origin, then the area bounded by the curve, the \(x\)-axis and the line \(x=1\), is the area between the curve and the \(x\)-axis from \(x=0\) to \(x=1\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Area \(=\int_0^1 f(x) d x\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Area \(=\int_0^1\left(x^2+x\right) d x\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Area \(=\frac{x^3}{3}+\left.\frac{x^2}{2}\right|_0 ^1\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Area \(=\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{2}=\frac{5 }{ 6}\)
What is the area under the curve \(f(x)=x e^x\) above the \(x\)-axis and between the lines \(x=0\) and \(x=1\)?

We know that the area under the curve \(f(x)\) above the \(x\)-axis and between the lines \(x = a\) and \(x = b\) is given by:

Area \(=\int_{ a }^{ b } f ( x ) dx\)

The area under the curve \(f(x)=x e^x\) above the \(x\)-axis and between the lines \(x=0\) and \(x=1\) is given by:

Area \(=\int_0^1 xe ^{ x } dx\)

Area \(=\left( xe ^{ x }- e ^{ x }\right)_0^1\)

Area \(=(1 . e-e)-(0-1)\)

Area \(=1\) square unit

Hence, the area under the curve \(f(x)=x e^x\) above the \(x\)-axis and between the lines \(x=0\) and \(x=1\) is 1 square unit.
The area bounded by \(y=\log x, x\) - axis and ordinates \(x=1, x=2\) is:

Area bounded by function \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\) is given as,


Area \(=\int_{ a }^{ b }[ f ( x )- g ( x )] dx =\int_{ a }^{ b }[\text { Top }- \text { bottom }] dx\)

Now,

Given: \(y =\log x\)

Area \(=\int_1^2 \log x dx\)

Apply by parts rule,

\(=[ x \log x ]_1^2-\int_1^2 \frac{1}{ x } \times xdx \)

\(=[ x \log x ]_1^2-[ x ]_1^2 \)

\(=[2 \log 2-\log 1]-[2-1] \)

\(=2 \log 2-1 \)

\(=\log 2^2-\log e \)

\(=\log 4-\log e \)

\(=\log \left(\frac{4}{ e }\right) \) sq. unit

\(=4 \times 0+6 \times 3+0 \times 4\)

\(=18\)

Then \(\beta\):

The equation of bisector of \(\overrightarrow{b}\) and \(\overrightarrow{c}\) is:

\(r=\lambda(\overrightarrow{b}+\overrightarrow{c})\)

\(=\lambda\left(\frac{\hat{i}+\hat{j}}{\sqrt{2}}+\frac{\hat{j}+\hat{k}}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\)

Since, vector a lies in plane of \(\overrightarrow{b}\) and \(\overrightarrow{c}\).

\(9\therefore \overrightarrow{a} = \overrightarrow{b }+\overrightarrow{c} \)

Put the given values in above equation:

\(\frac{\lambda}{\sqrt{2}}( \hat{i }+2 \hat{j} + \hat{k} )=( \hat{i} + \hat{j} )+\mu(\hat{ j} + \hat{k} )\)

On equating the coefficient of \(\hat{i}\) both sides, we get:

On putting \(\lambda=\sqrt{2}\) in Eq. (i), we get:

Since the given vector a represents the same bisector equation \(r\).

Given:

The vector \(-\hat{\mathrm{i}}+\hat{\mathrm{j}}+\hat{\mathrm{k}}\) bisects the angle between the vectors \(\vec{\mathrm{c}}\) and \(3 \hat{\mathrm{i}}+4 \hat{\mathrm{j}}\).

Let \(\hat{c}=x \hat{\mathrm{i}}+y \hat{\mathrm{j}}+z \hat{\mathrm{k}}\)

where \(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=1\)...(1)

Unit vector along \(3 \hat{\mathrm{i}}+4 \hat{\mathrm{j}}=\frac{3 \hat{\mathrm{i}}+4 \hat{\mathrm{j}}}{\sqrt{3^{2}+4^{2}}}\)

\(=\frac{3 \hat{\mathrm{i}}+4 \hat{\mathrm{j}}}{5}\)

The bisectors of these two is given by:

\(\mathrm{r} =\mathrm{t}(\hat{\mathrm{a}}+\hat{\mathrm{b}}) \)

\(\mathrm{r} =\mathrm{t}\left(\mathrm{x} \hat{\mathrm{i}}+\mathrm{y} \hat{\mathrm{j}}+\mathrm{x} \hat{\mathrm{k}}+\frac{3 \hat{\mathrm{i}}+4 \hat{\mathrm{j}}}{5}\right) \)

\(\mathrm{r} =\frac{\mathrm{t}}{5}[(5 \mathrm{x}+3) \hat{\mathrm{i}}+(5 \mathrm{y}+4) \hat{\mathrm{j}}+5 \mathrm{z} \hat{\mathrm{k}}) \)...(2)

But the bisector is given by \(-\hat{\mathrm{i}}+\hat{\mathrm{j}}-\hat{\mathrm{k}}\)...(3)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{x}=-\frac{5+3 \mathrm{t}}{5 \mathrm{t}} \)

\(\frac{\mathrm{t}}{5}(5 \mathrm{y}+4)=1\)

\( \Rightarrow \mathrm{y}=\frac{5-4 \mathrm{t}}{5 \mathrm{t}} \)

\(\frac{\mathrm{t}}{5}(5 \mathrm{z})=-1 \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{z}=-\frac{1}{\mathrm{t}}\)

Put all the values in equation (1), we get

\(\left(-\frac{5+3 t}{5 \mathrm{t}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{5-4 t}{5 \mathrm{t}}\right)^{2}+\left(-\frac{1}{\mathrm{t}}\right)^{2}=1 \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{25+9 \mathrm{t}^{2}+30 \mathrm{t}+25+16 \mathrm{t}^{2}-40 \mathrm{t}+25}{25 \mathrm{t}^{2}}=1 \)

\(\Rightarrow 25 \mathrm{t}^{2}-10 \mathrm{t}+75=25 \mathrm{t}^{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{t}=7.5\)

Thus,

\(\mathrm{x}=-\frac{5+3 \times 7.5}{5 \times 7.5}=-\frac{11}{15} \)

\(\mathrm{y}=\frac{5-4 \times 7.5}{5 \times 7.5}=-\frac{10}{15} \)

\(\mathrm{z}=-\frac{1}{7.5}=-\frac{2}{15} \)

\(\hat{c}=x \hat{\mathrm{i}}+y \hat{\mathrm{j}}+z \hat{\mathrm{k}}\)

So, \( \hat{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{1}{15}(-11 \hat{\mathrm{i}}-10 \hat{\mathrm{j}}-2 \hat{\mathrm{k}})\)

If the vectors \(\alpha \hat{\mathrm{i}}+\alpha \hat{\mathrm{j}}+\gamma \hat{\mathrm{k}}, \hat{\mathrm{i}}+\hat{\mathrm{k}}\) and \(\hat{\gamma}+\gamma \hat{\mathrm{j}}+\beta \hat{\mathrm{k}}\) lie on a plane, where \(\alpha, \beta\) and \(y\) are distinct non-negative numbers, then \(y\) is:

Given:

Vectors \(\alpha \hat{\mathrm{i}}+\alpha \hat{\mathrm{j}}+\gamma \hat{\mathrm{k}}, \hat{\mathrm{i}}+\hat{\mathrm{k}}\) and \(\hat{\gamma}+\gamma \hat{\mathrm{j}}+\beta \hat{\mathrm{k}}\) lie on a plane Vectors lie on the same plane so vectors are coplanar.

Condition for coplanarity: \(\vec{a} .(\vec{b} \times \vec{c})=\left|\begin{array}{lll}a_{1} & b_{1} & c_{1} \\ a_{2} & b_{2} & c_{2} \\ a_{3} & b_{3} & c_{3}\end{array}\right|=0\)

Therefore, \(\left|\begin{array}{lll}\alpha & \alpha & \gamma \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ \gamma & \gamma & \beta\end{array}\right|=0\)

On expanding, we get:

\( \alpha[0-\gamma]-\alpha[\beta-y]+\gamma[y-0]=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow-\alpha y-\alpha \beta+\alpha y+y^{2}=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow y^{2}=\alpha \beta\)

\(\therefore \alpha, \beta, \gamma\) are in G.P.
Vector triple product \(\mathrm{a} \times(\mathrm{b} \times \mathrm{c})\) of three vectors \(\mathrm{a}, \mathrm{b}\) and \(\mathrm{c}\) is given by:

The vector triple product is defined as the cross product of one vector with the cross product of the other two. The following relationship holds:

\(a\times (b\times c) = (a.c)b - (a.b)c\)

And also written as,

\(a\times (b \times c) = b (a.c) + c (a.b)\)

Given:

\(\vec{a}=4 \hat{i}+3 \hat{j}+4 \hat{k}\) and \(\vec{b}=6 \hat{i}+7 \hat{j}+8 \hat{k}\)

If \(\vec{a}=a_{1} \hat{i}+a_{2} \hat{j}+a_{3} \hat{k}\) and \(\vec{b}=b_{1} \hat{i}+b_{2} \hat{j}+b_{3} \hat{k}\) then \(\vec{a} \times \vec{b}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc} \hat{i} & \hat{j} & \hat{k} \\ a_{1} & a_{2} & a_{3} \\ b_{1} & b_{2} & b_{3} \end{array}\right|\)

\(\Rightarrow \vec{a} \times \vec{b}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\hat{i} & \hat{j} & \hat{k} \\ 4 & 3 & 4 \\ 6 & 7 & 8\end{array}\right|\)

\(\Rightarrow|\vec{a} \times \vec{b}|=\hat{i}(24-28)-\hat{j}(32-24)+\hat{k}(28-18)\)

\(=-4 \hat{i}-8 \hat{j}+10 \hat{k}\)

\(\Rightarrow|\vec{a} \times \vec{b}|=\sqrt{(-4)^{2}+(-8)^{2}+10^{2}}\)

\(=\sqrt{180}\)

\(=6 \sqrt{5}\)

If \(\vec{a}, \vec{b}, \vec{c}, \vec{d}\) are four vectors such that \(\vec{a}+\vec{b}+\vec{c}\) is collinear with \(\vec{d}\) and \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{b}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{c}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{d}}\) is collinear with \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}\), then \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{b}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{c}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{d}}\) is:

Given:

\(\vec{a}+\vec{b}+\vec{c}\) is collinear with \(\vec{d}\)

\(\Rightarrow(\vec{a}+\vec{b}+\vec{c}) \times \vec{d}=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow(\vec{a}+\vec{b}+\vec{c}) \times \vec{d}+\vec{d} \times \vec{d}=0(\because \vec{d} \times \vec{d}=0) \)

\(\Rightarrow(\vec{a}+\vec{b}+\vec{c}+\vec{d}) \times \vec{d}=0\).....(i)

Also given:

\(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{b}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{c}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{d}}\) is collinear with \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}\)

\(\Rightarrow(\vec{b}+\vec{c}+\vec{d}) \times \vec{a}=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow \vec{a} \times \vec{a}+(\vec{b}+\vec{c}+\vec{d}) \times \vec{a}=0(\because \vec{a} \times \vec{a}=0) \)

\(\Rightarrow(\vec{a}+\vec{b}+\vec{c}+\vec{d}) \times \vec{a}=0\).....(ii)

On adding (i) and (ii):

\((\vec{a}+\vec{b}+\vec{c}+\vec{d}) \times \vec{a}+(\vec{a}+\vec{b}+\vec{c}+\vec{d}) \times \vec{d}=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow(\vec{a}+\vec{b}+\vec{c}+\vec{d}) \times(\vec{a}+\vec{d})=0\).....(iii)

On subtracting (i) from (ii):

\((\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{b}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{c}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{d}}) \times \overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}-(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{b}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{c}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{d}}) \times \overrightarrow{\mathrm{d}}=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{b}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{c}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{d}}) \times(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}-\overrightarrow{\mathrm{d}})=0\)

From (iii) and (iv); it is clear that \((\vec{a}+\vec{b}+\vec{c}+\vec{d})\) is collinear to \((\vec{a}+\vec{d})\) and \((\vec{a}-\vec{d})\).

â and \(\hat{b}\) are two unit vectors

Equation (i) becomes,

Given:

\(\vec{a}=2 \hat{i}-6 \hat{j}-3 \hat{k}\) and \(\vec{b}=4 \hat{i}+3 \hat{j}-\hat{k}\)

\(|\vec{a}|=7,|\vec{b}|=\sqrt{26} \text { and } \vec{a} \cdot \vec{b}=-7 \)

\(\Rightarrow \cos \theta=\frac{\vec{a} \cdot \vec{b}}{|\vec{a}| \times|\vec{b}|}\)

Put all the given value in the above formula.

\(=\frac{-7}{7 \times \sqrt{26}}\)

\(=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{26}} \)

\(\because \sin ^{2} \theta=1-\cos ^{2} \theta\)

If in a right-angled triangle \(A B C\), hypotenuse \(A C=p\), then what is \(\overrightarrow{A B} \cdot \overrightarrow{A C}+\overrightarrow{B C} \cdot \overrightarrow{B A}+\overrightarrow{C A} \cdot \overrightarrow{C B}\) equal to:

Let the ratio be \(\lambda: 1\).

Position vector of point (C): \(\vec{c}=\frac{\lambda \vec{a}+\vec{b}}{\lambda+1}\)

Put the value of \(\vec{c}\) in \( 2 \vec{a}+3 \vec{b}-5 \vec{c}=0\)

\(2 \vec{a}+3 \vec{b}-5 \times\left(\frac{\lambda \vec{a}+\vec{b}}{\lambda+1}\right)=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\lambda}{1}=\frac{3}{2}\)

\(\begin{aligned}&X=\left[\begin{array}{ll}A_1 & A_2 & A_3 \\B_1 & B_2 & B_3\\C_1 & C_2 & C_3\end{array}\right], Y=\left[\begin{array}{ll}D_1 & D_2 & D_3 \\E_1 & E_2 & E_3\\F_1 & F_2 & F_3\end{array}\right] \\&X Y=\left[\begin{array}{ll}A_1 D_1+A_2 E_1+A_3F_1 & A_1 D_2+A_2 E_2+A_3F_2 &A_1 D_3+A_2 E_3+A_3F_3 \\B_1 D_1+B_2 E_1+B_3F_1 & B_1 D_2+B_2 E_2+B_3F_2 &B_1 D_3+B_2 E_3+B_3F_3 \\C_1 D_1+C_2 E_1+C_3F_1 & C_1 D_2+C_2 E_2+C_3F_2 &C_1 D_3+C_2 E_3+C_3F_3\end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\)

\(\Rightarrow A^2=\left[\begin{array}{lll}2(2)+0(2)+1(1) & 2(0)+0(1)+1(-1) & 2(1)+0(3)+1(0) \\ 2(2)+1(2)+3(1) & 2(0)+1(1)+3(-1) & 2(1)+1(3)+3(0) \\ 1(2)-1(2)+0(1) & 1(0)-1(1)+0(-1) & 1(1)-1(3)+0(0)\end{array}\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{A}^2=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}5 & -1 & 2 \\ 9 & -2 & 5 \\ 0 & -1 & -2\end{array}\right]\)

\(\therefore {A}^2-5 {~A}+6 {I}=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}5 & -1 & 2 \\ 9 & -2 & 5 \\ 0 & -1 & -2\end{array}\right]-5\left[\begin{array}{ccc}2 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 3 \\ 1 & -1 & 0\end{array}\right]+6\left[\begin{array}{lll}1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1\end{array}\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow {A}^2-5 {~A}+6 {I}=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}5 & -1 & 2 \\ 9 & -2 & 5 \\ 0 & -1 & -2\end{array}\right]-\left[\begin{array}{ccc}10 & 0 & 5 \\ 10 & 5 & 15 \\ 5 & -5 & 0\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{ccc}6 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 6 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 6\end{array}\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow {A}^2-5 {~A}+6 {I}=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}5-10 & -1-0 & 2-5 \\ 9-10 & -2-5 & 5-15 \\ 0-5 & -1+5 & -2-0\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{lll}6 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 6 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 6\end{array}\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow {A}^2-5 {~A}+6 {I}=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}-5 & -1 & -3 \\ -1 & -7 & -10 \\ -5 & 4 & -2\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{ccc}6 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 6 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 6\end{array}\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow A^2-5 A+6 I=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}1 & -1 & -3 \\ -1 & -1 & -10 \\ -5 & 4 & 4\end{array}\right]\)

Given: \(A=\left[\begin{array}{ll}3 & -2 \\ 4 & -2\end{array}\right]\)

\(\mathrm{A}^2=\mathrm{AA}\)

\(\Rightarrow A^2=\left[\begin{array}{ll}3 & -2 \\ 4 & -2\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{ll}3 & -2 \\ 4 & -2\end{array}\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow A^2=\left[\begin{array}{cc}9-8 & -6+4 \\ 12-8 & -8+4\end{array}\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow A^2=\left[\begin{array}{ll}1 & -2 \\ 4 & -4\end{array}\right]\)

Now, \(\mathrm{A}^2=\mathrm{kA}-2I\)

\(\Rightarrow\left[\begin{array}{cc}1 & -2 \\ 4 & -4\end{array}\right]=\mathrm{k}\left[\begin{array}{ll}3 & -2 \\ 4 & -2\end{array}\right]-2\left[\begin{array}{cc}1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1\end{array}\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow\left[\begin{array}{cc}1 & -2 \\ 4 & -4\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc}3 \mathrm{k} & -2 \mathrm{k} \\ 4 \mathrm{k} & -2 \mathrm{k}\end{array}\right]-\left[\begin{array}{cc}2 & 0 \\ 0 & 2\end{array}\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow\left[\begin{array}{cc}1 & -2 \\ 4 & -4\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc}3 \mathrm{k}-2 & -2 \mathrm{k} \\ 4 \mathrm{k} & -2 \mathrm{k}-2\end{array}\right]\)

Equating the corresponding elements, we have:

\(3 k-2=1\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{k}=1\)

Thus, the value of \(\mathrm{k}\) is 1 .
If \(A=\left[\begin{array}{cc}\cos \alpha & -\sin \alpha \\ \sin \alpha & \cos \alpha\end{array}\right]\), then \(A+A^{\prime}=I\), if the value of \(\alpha\) is:

Given \(A=\left[\begin{array}{cc}\cos \alpha & -\sin \alpha \\ \sin \alpha & \cos \alpha\end{array}\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{A}^{\prime}=\left[\begin{array}{cc}\cos \alpha & \sin \alpha \\ -\sin \alpha & \cos \alpha\end{array}\right]\)

Now, \(\because \mathrm{A}+\mathrm{A}^{\prime}=\mathrm{I}\)

\(\therefore\left[\begin{array}{cc}\cos \alpha & -\sin \alpha \\ \sin \alpha & \cos \alpha\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{cc}\cos \alpha & \sin \alpha \\ -\sin \alpha & \cos \alpha\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{ll}1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1\end{array}\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow\left[\begin{array}{cc}2 \cos \alpha & 0 \\ 0 & 2 \cos \alpha\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{ll}1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1\end{array}\right]\)

Equating the corresponding elements of the two matrices, we have:

\(\cos \alpha=\frac{1}{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \alpha=\cos ^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow \alpha=\frac{\pi}{3}\)

Given \(\left[\begin{array}{ccc}x & -5 & -1\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{lll}1 & 0 & 2 \\ 0 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 0 & 3\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l}x \\ 4 \\ 1\end{array}\right]=0\)

\(\Rightarrow\left[\begin{array}{lll}x-2 & -10 & 2 x-8\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}x \\ 4 \\ 1\end{array}\right]=0\)

\(\Rightarrow[x(x-2)-40+2 x-8]=0\)

\(\Rightarrow\left[x^2-48\right]=[0]\)

\(\Rightarrow x^2-48=0\)

\(\therefore x=\pm 4 \sqrt{3}\)

Thus, the required value of \(x\) is \(\pm 4 \sqrt{3}\).
Find out a \(2 \times 2\) matrix \(A=\left[a_{i j}\right]\) whose elements are given by \(a_{i j}=\frac{(i+2 j)^2}{2}\).

\(a_{i j}=\frac{(i+2 j)^2}{2}, 1 \leq i \leq 2\) and \(1 \leq j \leq 2\)

Therefore,

\(a_{11}=\frac{(1+2 \times 1)^2}{2}=\frac{(1+2)^2}{2}=\frac{9}{2}\)

\(a_{12}=\frac{(1+2 \times 2)^2}{2}=\frac{25}{2}\)

\(a_{21}=\frac{(2+2 \times 1)^2}{2}=8\) 

and \(a_{22}=\frac{(2+2 \times 2)^2}{2}=18\)

So the required matrix is \(A=\left[\begin{array}{ll}a_{11} & a_{12} \\ a_{21} & a_{22}\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc}\frac{9}{2} & \frac{25}{2} \\ 8 & 18\end{array}\right]\)
Find the value of \(x, y, z\) and \(w\) such that \(\left[\begin{array}{cc}x-y & 2 z+w \\ 2 x-y & 2 x+w\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc}5 & 3 \\ 12 & 15\end{array}\right]\).

We know that the corresponding elements of two equal matrices are equal.

\(\begin{aligned} & \therefore \quad\left[\begin{array}{cc} x-y & 2 z+w \\ 2 x-y & 2 x+w \end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc} 5 & 3 \\ 12 & 15 \end{array}\right] \\ & \Rightarrow \quad x-y=5,2 z+w=3,2 x-y=12 \text { and } 2 x+w=15 \end{aligned}\)

Solving \(x-y=5\) and \(2 x-y=12\) as simultaneous linear equations, we get \(x=7, y=2\).

Putting \(x=7\) in equation \(2 x+w=15\), we get

\(14+w=15 \Rightarrow w=1\)

Putting \(w=1\) in \(2 z+w=3\), we get

\(2 z+1=3 \Rightarrow z=1\)

Hence, \( x=7, y=2, z=1\) and \(w=1\)

For what values of \(x\) and \(y\) are the following matrices equal:

\(A=\left[\begin{array}{cc} 2 x+1 & 3 y \\ 0 & y^2-5 y\end{array}\right], B=\left[\begin{array}{cc}x+3 & y^2+2 \\0 & -6\end{array}\right]\)

Since the corresponding elements of two equal matrices are equal.

Therefore \(A=B\)

\(\Rightarrow 2 x+1=x+3\), 

and \(3 y=y^2+2\) 

and \(y^2-5 y=-6\) 

Now, \(2 x+1=x+3\) 

\(\Rightarrow x=2, \quad 3 y=y^2+2\) 

\(\Rightarrow y^2-3 y+2=0\) 

\(\Rightarrow y=1,2\) 

and \(y^2-5 y=-6\) 

\(\Rightarrow y^2-5 y+6=0\) 

\(\Rightarrow y=2,3\)

Since \(3 y=y^2+2\) and \(y^2-5 y=-6\) have equal values of \(y\). 

Therefore \(y=2\)

Hence, \(A=B\) if \(x=2, y=2\).

Let \(B=\left[\begin{array}{rr}2 & 3 \\ -1 & 4\end{array}\right]\) and \(C=\left[\begin{array}{rr}3 & -6 \\ -3 & 8\end{array}\right]\). 

Then, the given matrix equation is \(A+B=C\).

Now, \( A+B=C\)

\(\Rightarrow (A+B)+(-B)=C+(-B) \)

\(\Rightarrow  A+(B+(-B)=C+(-B) \)

\(\Rightarrow  A+0=C-B \)

\(\Rightarrow  A=C-B \)

\(\therefore  A=\left[\begin{array}{rr} 3 & -6 \\ -3 & 8 \end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{rr} -2 & -3 \\ 1 & -4  \end{array}\right]\)

\(A=\left[\begin{array}{rr} 3-2 & -6-3 \\ -3+1 & 8-4 \end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 & -9 \\ -2 & 4 \end{array}\right]\)

\(\begin{array}{ll}\Rightarrow & {\left[\begin{array}{l}x^2 \\ y^2\end{array}\right]-\left[\begin{array}{l}3 x \\ 6 y\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{r}-2 \\ 9\end{array}\right]} \\ \Rightarrow & {\left[\begin{array}{l}x^2-3 x \\ y^2-6 y\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{r}-2 \\ 9\end{array}\right]} \\ \Rightarrow & x^2-3 x=-2 \text { and } y^2-6 y=9 \\ \Rightarrow & x^2-3 x+2=0 \text { and } y^2-6 y-9=0 \\ \Rightarrow & (x-1)(x-2)=0 \text { and } y=\frac{6 \pm \sqrt{36+36}}{2} \\ \Rightarrow & x=1,2 \text { and } y=3 \pm 3 \sqrt{2}\end{array}\)
Use matrix multiplication to find out the two parts of Rs. 30,000 such that the total annual interest at \(9 \%\) on the first part and \(11 \%\) on the second part amounts Rs. 3060.

Let the two parts be Rs. \(x\) and Rs. \((30000-x)\) respectively. 

Let \(A\) be the \(1 \times 2\) matrix representing these two parts

i.e. \(\left[A=\begin{array}{ll}x & 30000-x\end{array}\right]\)

Let \(R\) denote the \(2 \times 1\) matrix representing the annual interest rates of interest on two parts.

i.e. \(R=\begin{aligned} & \text { Part I } \\ & \text { Part II } \end{aligned}\left[\begin{array}{l} 0.09 \\ 0.11 \end{array}\right]\)

The total annual interest on the two parts is given by the matrix multiplication \(A R\).

\(\begin{array}{ll} \therefore & A R=3060 \\ \Rightarrow & {\left[\begin{array}{ll} x & 30000-x  \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l} 0.09 \\ 0.11 \end{array}\right]=3060} \\ \Rightarrow & 0.09 x+0.11(30000-x)=3060 \\ \Rightarrow & \frac{9}{100} x+\frac{11}{100}(30000-x)=3060 \\ \Rightarrow & 9 x+330000-11 x=306000 \Rightarrow x=12,000 \end{array}\)

Hence two parts of Rs 30,000 are Rs 12,000 and Rs. 18,000 respectively.
If \(A=\left[\begin{array}{rrr}1 & 2 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 & -2 \\ a & 2 & b\end{array}\right]\) is a matrix satisfying \(A A^T=9 I_3\), then find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

We have,

\(\begin{aligned} & A=\left[\begin{array}{rrr}1 & 2 & 2 \\  2 & 1 & -2 \\ a & 2 & b \end{array}\right] \\ & \Rightarrow \quad A^T=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 & 2 & a \\ 2 & 1 & 2 \\ 2 & -2 & b \end{array}\right] \\ & \therefore \quad A A^T=9 I_3 \\ & \Rightarrow \quad\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 & 2 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 & -2 \\ a & 2 & b \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 & 2 & a \\ 2 & 1 & 2 \\2 & -2 & b \end{array}\right]=9\left[\begin{array}{lll} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array}\right] \\ & \Rightarrow \quad\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 9 & 0 & a+2 b+4 \\ 0 & 9 & 2 a+2-2 b \\ a+2 b+4 & 2 a+2-2 b & a^2+4+b^2  \end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 9 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 9 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 9 \end{array}\right]\\ \end{aligned}\)

\(\Rightarrow  a+2 b+4=0,2 a+2-2 b=0\)  and \(a^2+4+b^2=9 \)

\(\Rightarrow  a+2 b+4=0, a-b+1=0\) and \(a^2+b^2=5 \)

Solving \(a+2 b+4=0\) and \(a-b+1=0\)

We get \(a=-2, b=-1 \)

There are two families \(A\) and \(B\). There are 4 men, 6 women and 2 children in family A and 2 men, 2 women and 4 children in family B. The recommended daily allowance for calories is : Man : 2400 , woman : 1900 , child : 1800 and for proteins is - Man : 55 gm, woman : 45 gm and child : 33 gm.

Represent the above information by matrices. Using matrix multiplication, calculate the total requirement of calories for each of the two families.

The members of the two families can be represented by the \(2 \times 3\) matrix

\(F=\begin{gathered}M \\ A \\ B\end{gathered}\left[\begin{array}{ccc}M & W & C \\ 4 & 6 & 2 \\ 2 & 2 & 4\end{array}\right]\)

and the recommended daily allowance of calories and proteins for each member can be represented by \(3 \times 2\) matrix

\(F=\begin{gathered}M \\ A \\ B\end{gathered}\left[\begin{array}{cc}M & W & \\ 2400 & 55 \\1900 & 45 &  \\ 1800 & 33 \end{array}\right]\)

The total requirement of calories and proteins for each of the two families is given by the matrix multiplication :

\(F R=\left[\begin{array}{lll} 4 & 6 & 2 \\ 2 & 2 & 4 \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{ll} 2400 & 55 \\ 1900 & 45 \\ 1800 & 33 \end{array}\right]\)

\(F R= \begin{gathered} & A \\ &B\end{gathered}\left[\begin{array}{ll} 24600 & 556 \\ 15800 & 332 \end{array} \right]\)

So, family A requires 24600 calories and family B requires 15800 calories.
Find the values of \(x, y, z\) if the matrix \(A=\left[\begin{array}{rrr}0 & 2 y & z \\ x & y & -z \\ x & -y & z\end{array}\right]\) satisfy the equation \(A^T A=I_3\).

We have,

\(\begin{aligned} & A=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 & 2 y & z \\ x & y & -z \\ x & -y & z \end{array}\right] \Rightarrow A^T=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 & x & x \\ 2 y & y & -y \\ z & -z & z \end{array}\right] \\ \therefore  & A^T A=I_3 \\ \Rightarrow & {\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 & x & x \\ 2 y & y & -y \\ z & -z & z \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 & 2 y & z \\ x & y & -z \\ x & -y & z \end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{lll} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\0 & 0 & 1\end{array}\right] } \\ \Rightarrow & {\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 2 x^2 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 6 y^2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 3 z^2 \end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{lll} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array}\right] }& \\ \Rightarrow & 2 x^2=1,6 y^2=1,3 z^2=1 \\ \Rightarrow  & x= \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}, y= \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{6}}, z= \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \end{aligned}\)
If \(A B=A\) and \(B A=B\), then show that \(A^2=A, B^2=?\)

We have,

\(A B=A\) and \(B A=B \)

Now,\(A B=A \)

\((A B) A=A A \)

\(\Rightarrow  A(B A)=A^2 \)

\(\Rightarrow   A B=A^2 \)

\(\Rightarrow  A=A^2 \)

Similarly, we have \(B^2=B\)

If \(a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3},=t_{9}, a_{9}\) are in GP, then what is the value of the following determinant?

\(\left|\begin{array}{lll}\ln a_{1} & \ln a_{2} & \ln a_{3} \\ \ln a_{4} & \ln a_{5} & \ln a_{6} \\ \ln a_{7} & \ln a_{8} & \ln a_{9}\end{array}\right|\)

Let \({r}\) be the common ratio of the given GP

Now,

\(\left|\begin{array}{lll}\ln a_{1} & \ln a_{2} & \ln a_{3} \\ \ln a_{4} & \ln a_{5} & \ln a_{6} \\ \ln a_{7} & \ln a_{8} & \ln a_{9}\end{array}\right|\)

Apply, \(\mathrm{C}_{2} \rightarrow \mathrm{C}_{2}-\mathrm{C}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{C}_{3} \rightarrow \mathrm{C}_{3}-\mathrm{C}_{1}\)

\(\begin{aligned}&=\left|\begin{array}{lll}\ln a_{1} & \ln a_{2}-\ln a_{1} & \ln a_{3}-\ln a_{2} \\ \ln a_{4} & \ln a_{5}-\ln a_{4} & \ln a_{6}-\ln a_{5} \\ \ln a_{7} & \ln a_{8}-\ln a_{7} & \ln a_{9}-\ln a_{8}\end{array}\right| \\&=\left|\begin{array}{lll}\ln a_{1} & \ln r & \ln r \\ \ln a_{4} & \ln r & \ln r \\ \ln a_{7} & \ln r & \ln r\end{array}\right| \quad\left[\text { Since, } \frac{a_{p+1}}{a_{p}}=r \text { and } \log a_{p+1}-\log a_{p}=\log \frac{a_{p+1}}{a_{p}}=\log \right]\end{aligned}\)

\(=0\qquad  \qquad{\left[\text { Since, } \text{C}_{3}=\text{C}_{2}\right]}\)
Find the value of \(\left|\begin{array}{lll}0 & c & b \\ c & 0 & a \\ b & a & 0\end{array}\right|^{2}\).

Given determinant is \(\left|\begin{array}{lll}0 & c & b \\ c & 0 & a \\ b & a & 0\end{array}\right|^{2}\), simplifying the determinant based on first row we get,

\(=\left\{0 \times\left(0-a^{2}\right)-c \times(c \times 0-b \times a)+b(c \times a-b \times 0)\right\}^{2}\)

\(=(a b c+a b c)^{2}\)

\(=4 a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}\)

If \(\omega\) is the cube root of unity, then what is the value of:

\(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & \omega & \omega^{2} \\ \omega & \omega^{2} & 1 \\ \omega^{2} & 1 & \omega\end{array}\right|\)

If the \(1, \omega\) and \(\omega^{2}\) are the cube roots of unity, then \(1+\omega+\omega^{2}=0\)

If any row and column have all the elements as zero in the square matrix, then the determinant is zero.

\(\mathrm{D}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & \omega & \omega^{2} \\ \omega & \omega^{2} & 1 \\ \omega^{2} & 1 & \omega\end{array}\right|\)

\(\mathrm{R}_{3}=\mathrm{R}_{3}+\mathrm{R}_{1}+\mathrm{R}_{2}\)

\(\mathrm{D}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & \omega & 1+\omega+\omega^{2} \\ \omega & \omega^{2} & 1+\omega+\omega^{2} \\ \omega^{2} & 1 & 1+\omega+\omega^{2}\end{array}\right|\)

\(\mathrm{D}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & \omega & 0 \\ \omega & \omega^{2} & 0 \\ \omega^{2} & 1 & 0\end{array}\right|=0\)

If \(x,y,z\) are all different and not equal to zero and \(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1+x & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1+y & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1+z\end{array}\right|=0\) then the value of \(x^{-1}+y^{-1}+z^{-1}\) is equal to:

\(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1+x & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1+y & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1+z\end{array}\right|=0\)

\(R_{1}=R_{1}-R_{2}\)

\(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}x & -y & 0 \\ 1 & 1+y & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1+z\end{array}\right|=0\)

\(R_{2}=R_{2}-R_{3}\)

\(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}x & -y & 0 \\ 0 & y & -z \\ 1 & 1 & 1+z\end{array}\right|=0\)

Now, Expanding along \(R_{1}\), we get:

\(x[y(1+z)-(-z)]-(-y)[0-(-z)]+0=0\)

\(\Rightarrow x[y+y z+z]+y[z]=0\)

\(\Rightarrow x y+x y z+x z+y z=0\)

Dividing by \({xyz}\),

\(\frac{1}{\mathrm{z}}+1+\frac{1}{\mathrm{y}}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{x}}=0\)

\(\Rightarrow {x}^{-1}+{y}^{-1}+{z}^{-1}=-{1}\)

What is the value of the determinant \(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\mathrm{i} & \mathrm{i}^{2} & \mathrm{i}^{3} \\ \mathrm{i}^{4} & \mathrm{i}^{6} & \mathrm{i}^{8} \\ \mathrm{i}^{9} & \mathrm{i}^{12} & \mathrm{i}^{15}\end{array}\right|\) where \(\mathrm{i}=\sqrt{-1} ?\)

Given determinant is \(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\mathrm{i} & \mathrm{i}^{2} & \mathrm{i}^{3} \\ \mathrm{i}^{4} & \mathrm{i}^{6} & \mathrm{i}^{8} \\ \mathrm{i}^{9} & \mathrm{i}^{12} & \mathrm{i}^{15}\end{array}\right|\)

Since, we have,

\(\mathrm{i}=\sqrt{-1}\)

\(\mathrm{i}^{2}=-1, \mathrm{i}^{3}=-\mathrm{i}, \mathrm{i}^{4}=1, \mathrm{i}^{6}=-1, \mathrm{i}^{8}=1, \mathrm{i}^{9}=\mathrm{i}, \mathrm{i}^{12}=1\), and \(\mathrm{i}^{15}=-\mathrm{i}\)

\(=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\mathrm{i} & -1 & -\mathrm{i} \\ 1 & -1 & 1 \\ \mathrm{i} & 1 & -\mathrm{i}\end{array}\right|\)

\(=\mathrm{i}(\mathrm{i}-1)+1(-\mathrm{i}-\mathrm{i})-\mathrm{i}(1+\mathrm{i})\)

\(=i^{2}-i-2 i-i-i^{2}\)

\(=-4 i\)
A determinant (Δ) of 3 rows (R1, R2, R3) and 3 columns (C1, C2, C3) has a value Δ = 15. If two columns C2 and C3 of determinant (Δ) are interchanged, then the value of determinant will be

Given,

Determinant (Δ) = 15

Two columns C2 and C3 of determinant (Δ) are interchanged

From the properties of the determinants:

If any two rows (or columns) of a determinant are interchanged, then sign of determinant changes.

Hence the value of determinant will be Δ = -15
The value of \(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}a & b & c \\ b+c & c+a & a+b \\ a^2 & b^2 & c^2\end{array}\right|\)

Given,

\(A=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}a & b & c \\ b+c & c+a & a+b \\ a^2 & b^2 & c^2\end{array}\right|\)

Applying the column operations

\(C _1 \rightarrow C _1- C _2\) and \(C _2 \rightarrow C _2- C _3\)

\(A=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}a-b & b-c & c \\ b-a & c-b & a+b \\ a^2-b^2 & b^2-c^2 & c^2\end{array}\right|\)

\(\Rightarrow(a-b)(b-c)\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 1 & c \\ -1 & -1 & a+b \\ a+b & b+c & c^2\end{array}\right|\)

Taking common (a-b) and (b-c) From first and second column respectively.

\(\Rightarrow(a-b)(b-c)\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 1 & c \\ -1 & -1 & a+b \\ a+b & b+c & c^2\end{array}\right|\)

Applying column operation \(C_1 \rightarrow C_1-C_2\)

\(\Rightarrow(a-b)(b-c)\left|\begin{array}{ccc}0 & 1 & c \\ 0 & -1 & a+b \\ a-c & b+c & c^2\end{array}\right|\)

Now solving the determinant we get,

\(A=(a-b)(b-c)[(a-c) \times\{(a+b)-(-c)\}] \)

\(A=-(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)(a+b+c)\)
The value of \(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\sin ^2 x & \cos ^2 x & 1 \\ \cos ^2 x & \sin ^2 x & 1 \\ -10 & 12 & 2\end{array}\right|\)

Let \(\Delta=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\sin ^2 x & \cos ^2 x & 1 \\ \cos ^2 x & \sin ^2 x & 1 \\ -10 & 12 & 2\end{array}\right|\)

Applying \(C _1 \rightarrow C _1+ C _2\), we get:

\(\Delta=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\sin ^2 x+\cos ^2 x & \cos ^2 x & 1 \\ \cos ^2 x+\sin ^2 x & \sin ^2 x & 1 \\ -10+12 & 12 & 2\end{array}\right|\)

\(\Delta=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & \cos ^2 x & 1 \\ 1 & \sin ^2 x & 1 \\ 2 & 12 & 2\end{array}\right| \quad\left(\because \sin ^2 x+\cos ^2 x=1\right)\)

As we know, if two rows or two columns of a determinant are identical the value of the determinant is zero.

Here \(C_1\) and \(C_3\) are identical.

So, \(\Delta=0\)

If \(a, b, c\) are real numbers, then the value of the determinant

\(\left|\begin{array}{lll}1-a & a-b-c & b+c \\ 1-b & b-c-a & c+a \\ 1-c & c-a-b & a+b\end{array}\right|\)

Let \(\Delta=\left|\begin{array}{lll}1-a & a-b-c & b+c \\ 1-b & b-c-a & c+a \\ 1-c & c-a-b & a+b\end{array}\right|\)

Applying \(C _2 \rightarrow C _2+ C _3\), we get:

\(\Delta=\left|\begin{array}{lll}1-a & a & b+c \\ 1-b & b & c+a \\ 1-c & c & a+b\end{array}\right|\)

Applying \(C _1 \rightarrow C _1+ C _2, C _3 \rightarrow C _3+ C _2\) we get:

\(\Delta=\left|\begin{array}{lll}1 & a & a+b+c \\ 1 & b & b+c+a \\ 1 & c & c+a+b\end{array}\right|\)

Taking common \(a + b + c\) from \(C _3\), we get:

\(\Delta=(a+b+c)\left|\begin{array}{lll}1 & a & 1 \\ 1 & b & 1 \\ 1 & c & 1\end{array}\right|\)

We know that if two columns of a determinant are identical, the value of the determinant is zero.

\(\therefore \Delta=0\)

If \(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}a & b & 0 \\ 0 & a & b \\ b & 0 & a\end{array}\right|=0\)

then which one of the following is correct?
\(\frac{a}{b}\) is one of the cube roots of unity
\(\frac{a}{b}\) is one of the cube roots of \(-1\)
a is one of the cube roots of unity
\(b\) is one of the cube roots of unity

Solving a \(3 \times 3\) determinant:

A \(3 \times 3\) determinant can be solved as follows:

\(\left|\begin{array}{lll}a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i\end{array}\right|=a(e i-f h)-b(d i-f g)+c(d h-g e)\)

Given

Simplify the given determinant as follows:

\(\left|\begin{array}{lll}a & b & 0 \\ 0 & a & b \\ b & 0 & a\end{array}\right|=0\)

\(a\left(a^2-0\right)-b\left(0-b^2\right)+0(0-a b)=0\)

\(\begin{aligned} a^3+b^3 &=0 \\ a^3 &=-b^3 \\ \frac{a^3}{b^3} &=-1 \end{aligned}\)

Therefore, the given condition holds only if \(\frac{a}{b}\) is one of the cube roots of \(-1\)
\(\left|\begin{array}{lll}a+b & a & b \\ a & a+c & c \\ b & c & b+c\end{array}\right|=\)

\(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}a+b & a & b \\ a & a+c & c \\ b & c & b+c\end{array}\right|\)

\(=(a+b)\left[(a+c)(b+c)-c^2\right]-a[a b+a c-b c]+b[a c-a b-b c]\)

\(=(a+b)[a b+a c+c b]-a^2 b-a^2 c+a b c+a b c-a b^2-b^2 c\)

\(=a^2 b+a^2 c+a b c+a b^2+a b c+b^2+a b c+c b^2-a^2 b-a^2 c+\)

\(a b c+a b c-a b^2-b^2 c\)

\(=4 a b c\)

What is the value of the following determinant?

\(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\cos C & \tan A & 0 \\ \sin B & 0 & -\tan A \\ 0 & \sin B & \cos C \end{array}\right|\)

Formula used 

\(A =\left|\begin{array}{lll}a_1 & a_2 & a_3 \\ b_1 & b_2 & b_3 \\ c_1 & c_2 & c_3\end{array}\right|\)

\(\operatorname{det}( A )= a _1\left|\begin{array}{ll}b_2 & b_3 \\ c_2 & c_3\end{array}\right|- a _2\left|\begin{array}{ll}b_1 & b_3 \\ c_1 & c_3\end{array}\right|+ a _3\left|\begin{array}{ll}b_1 & b_2 \\ c_1 & c_2\end{array}\right|\)

\(=a_1\left(b_2 c_3-b_3 c_2\right)-a_2\left(b_1 c_3-b_3 c_1\right)+a_3\left(b_1 c_2-b_2 c_1\right)\)

Given

\(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\cos C & \tan A & 0 \\ \sin B & 0 & -\tan A \\ 0 & \sin B & \cos C\end{array}\right|\)

\(=\cos C(0+\tan A \sin B)-\tan A(\sin B \cos C)\)

\(=\tan A \sin B \cos C-\tan A \sin B \cos C\)

\(=0\)
The value of \(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1+ x & 2 & 3 \\ 1 & 2+ x & 3 \\ 1 & 2 & 3+ x \end{array}\right|\) is

\(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1+ x & 2 & 3 \\ 1 & 2+ x & 3 \\ 1 & 2 & 3+ x \end{array}\right|\)

\(R_1 \rightarrow R_1-R_2\) and \(R_2 \rightarrow R_2-R_3\)

\(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}x & -x & 0 \\ 0 & x & -x \\ 1 & 2 & 3+x\end{array}\right|\)

\(=x\left(x^2+3 x-(-2 x)\right)+1\left(x^2\right) \ldots \ldots .\left[\right.\) Expanding along \(\left.C_1\right]\)

\(=x\left(x^2+5 x\right)+x^2\)

\(=x^3+6 x^2\)

\(=x^2(x+6)\)

An equilateral triangle has each side equal to \(a\). If the co-ordinates of its vertices are \(\left(x_1\right.\), \(\left.y _1\right) ;\left( x _2, y _2\right):\left( x _3, y _3\right)\) then the square of the determinant \(\left|\begin{array}{lll}x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1\end{array}\right|\) equals:

Concept:

Area of equilateral triangle \(=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \times a ^2\)

Given

Given: The co-ordinates of its vertices are \(\left(x_1, y_1\right) ;\left(x_2, y_2\right):\left(x_3, y_3\right)\) then the square of

the determinant \(\left|\begin{array}{lll}x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1\end{array}\right|\)

\(\Rightarrow(\triangle ABC )=\frac{1}{2}\left|\begin{array}{lll}x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1\end{array}\right|=\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}\right) \times a ^2\)

On squaring both side,

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{4}\left|\begin{array}{lll}x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1\end{array}\right|^2=\frac{3 a^4}{16}\)

\(\Rightarrow\left|\begin{array}{lll}x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1\end{array}\right|^2=\frac{3 a^4}{4}\)
If the lines \(L_1: \lambda^2 x-y-1=0 L_2: x-\lambda^2 y+1=0 L_3: x+y-\lambda^2=0\) pass through the same point the value(s) of \(\lambda\) equals

The given equations passes through same point.So, they are concurrent lines

\(\Rightarrow\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\lambda^2 & -1 & -1 \\ 1 & -\lambda^2 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & -\lambda^2\end{array}\right|=0\)

\(\Rightarrow \lambda^6-3 \lambda^2-2=0\)

By doing synthetic division we get,

\(\left(\lambda^4-2 \lambda^2+1\right)\left(\lambda^2-2\right)=0 \)

\(\left(\lambda^2-1\right)^2\left(\lambda^2-2\right)=0 \)

\(\lambda=\pm \sqrt{2} \text { or } \lambda=\pm 1\)

But here \(\lambda=\pm 1\) does not satisfies, hence \(\lambda=\sqrt{2}\)

If Δ is the value of the determinant 

\(\left|\begin{array}{lll}a_1 & b_1 & c_1 \\ a_2 & b_2 & c_2 \\ a_3 & b_3 & c_3\end{array}\right|\)

then what is the value of the following determinant?

\(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}p a_1 & b_1 & q c_1 \\ p a_2 & b_2 & q c_2 \\ p a_3 & b_3 & q c_3\end{array}\right|\)

(p ≠ 0 or 1, q ≠ 0 or 1)

Concept:

Using Scalar Multiple Property:

If all the elements of a row (or column) of a determinant are multiplied by a non-zero constant, then the determinant gets multiplied by the same constant.

Given,

Δ\(=\left|\begin{array}{lll}a_1 & b_1 & c_1 \\ a_2 & b_2 & c_2 \\ a_3 & b_3 & c_3\end{array}\right|\)

Column 1 of all elements is multiplied by p then given matrices is also multiplied by p

pΔ\(=\left|\begin{array}{lll}p a_1 & b_1 & c_1 \\ p a_2 & b_2 & c_2 \\ p a_3 & b_3 & c_3\end{array}\right|\)

Again column 3 of all elements is multiplied by q then given matrices is also multiplied by q

pqΔ\(=\left|\begin{array}{lll}p a_1 & b_1 & q c_1 \\ p a_2 & b_2 & q c_2 \\ p a_3 & b_3 & q c_3\end{array}\right|\)
Find the determinant of the matrix \(\left|\begin{array}{ccc} x & y & z \\ a & b & c \\ x + a & y + b & z + c \end{array}\right|\)

Concept:

Properties of Determinant of a Matrix:

- If each entry in any row or column of a determinant is 0 , then the value of the determinant is zero.

- For any square matrix say \(A ,| A |=\left| A ^{\top}\right|\).

- If we interchange any two rows (columns) of a matrix, the determinant is multiplied by \(-1\).

- If any two rows (columns) of a matrix are same then the value of the determinant is zero.

Given

\(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}x & y & z \\ a & b & c \\ x+a & y+b & z+c\end{array}\right|\)

Apply \(R_1 \rightarrow R_1+R_2\)

\(=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}x+a & y+b & z+c \\ a & b & c \\ x+a & y+b & z+c\end{array}\right|\)

As we can see that the first and the third row of the given matrix are equal.

We know that, if any two rows (columns) of a matrix are same then the value of the determinant is zero.

\(\left|\begin{array}{ccc} x & y & z \\ a & b & c \\ x + a & y + b & z + c \end{array}\right|=0\)
If \(a , b , c\) are sides of a scalene triangle, then the value of \(\left|\begin{array}{ccc} a & b & c \\ b & c & a \\ c & a & b \end{array}\right|\) is :

\(\left|\begin{array}{lll}a & b & c \\ b & c & a \\ c & a & b\end{array}\right|\)

\(=a\left(b c-a^2\right)-b\left(b^2-a c\right)+c\left(a b-c^2\right)\)

\(=a b c-a^3-b^3+a b c+a b c-c^3\)

\(=-\left[a^3+b^3+c^3-3 a b c\right]\)

\(=-(a+b+c)\left(a^2+b^2+c^2-a b-b c-c a\right)\)

\(=-\frac{(a+b+c)}{2}\left(2 a^2+2 b^2+2 c^2-2 a b-2 b c-2 c a\right)\)

\(=-\frac{(a+b+c)}{2}\left(a^2-2 a b+b^2+b^2-2 b c+c^2+c^2-2 c a+a^2\right)\)

\(=-\frac{a+b+c}{2}\left[(a-b)^2+(b-c)^2+(c-a)^2\right]\).

Value obtained is negative.
Therefore, the value of \(\left|\begin{array}{lll}a & b & c \\ b & c & a \\ c & a & b\end{array}\right|\) is negative.
Evaluate \(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}a^2 & a^2-(b-c)^2 & b c \\ b^2 & b^2-(c-a)^2 & c a \\ c^2 & c^2-(a-b)^2 & a b\end{array}\right|\) :

Let the value of the given determinant be \(\Delta\). Then,

\(\Delta=\left|\begin{array}{lll}a^2 & a^2-(b-c)^2 & b c \\ b^2 & b^2-(c-a)^2 & c a \\ c^2 & c^2-(a-b)^2 & a b\end{array}\right|\)

\(=\left|\begin{array}{lll}a^2 & -(b-c)^2 & b c \\ b^2 & -(c-a)^2 & c a \\ c^2 & -(a-b)^2 & a b\end{array}\right| \quad\) [applying \(\left.C_2 \rightarrow\left(C_2-C_1\right)\right]\)

\(=(-1) \cdot\left|\begin{array}{ccc}a^2 & (b-c)^2 & b c \\ b^2 & (c-a)^2 & c a \\ c^2 & (a-b)^2 & a b\end{array}\right|\)

\(=(-1) \cdot\left|\begin{array}{lll}a^2 & b^2+c^2-2 b c & b c \\ b^2 & c^2+a^2-2 c a & c a \\ c^2 & a^2+b^2-2 a b & a b\end{array}\right|\)

\(=(-1) \cdot\left|\begin{array}{lll}a^2 & a^2+b^2+c^2 & b c \\ b^2 & a^2+b^2+c^2 & c a \\ c^2 & a^2+b^2+c^2 & a b\end{array}\right| \quad\left[C_2 \rightarrow C_2+C_1+2 C_3\right]\)

\(=(-1)\left(a^2+b^2+c^2\right) \cdot\left|\begin{array}{lll}a^2 & 1 & b c \\ b^2 & 1 & c a \\ c^2 & 1 & a b\end{array}\right|\)

\(=(-1)\left(a^2+b^2+c^2\right) \cdot\left|\begin{array}{ccc}a^2 & 1 & b c \\ b^2-a^2 & 0 & (a-b) c \\ c^2-a^2 & 0 & (a-c) b\end{array}\right|\)

[taking out \((b-a)\) common from \(R_2\) and \((c-a)\) common from \(R_3\) ] \(=(-1)\left(a^2+b^2+c^2\right)(b-a)(c-a)(-1) \cdot\left|\begin{array}{cc}b+a & -c \\ c+a & -b\end{array}\right|\)

\(=\left(a^2+b^2+c^2\right)(b-a)(c-a) \cdot(-1) \cdot\left|\begin{array}{ll}b+a & c \\ c+a & b\end{array}\right|\)

\(=\left(a^2+b^2+c^2\right)(a-b)(c-a) \cdot\{b(b+a)-c(c+a)\}\)

\(=\left(a^2+b^2+c^2\right)(a-b)(c-a) \cdot\left\{\left(b^2-c^2\right)+(a b-a c)\right\}\)

\(=\left(a^2+b^2+c^2\right)(a-b)(c-a) \cdot\left\{\left(b^2-c^2\right)+a(b-c)\right\}\)

\(=\left(a^2+b^2+c^2\right)(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)(a+b+c)\).

\(\Delta=\left(a^2+b^2+c^2\right)(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)(a+b+c)\)

Let the given determinant be \(\Delta\). Then,

\(\Delta=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\cos \alpha \cos \beta & \cos \alpha \sin \beta & -\sin \alpha \\ -\sin \beta & \cos \beta & 0 \\ \sin \alpha \cos \beta & \sin \alpha \sin \beta & \cos \alpha\end{array}\right|\)

\(=\frac{1}{\sin \alpha \cos \alpha} \cdot\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\sin \alpha \cos \alpha \cos \beta & \sin \alpha \cos \alpha \sin \beta & -\sin ^2 \alpha \\ -\sin \beta & \cos \beta & 0 \\ \sin \alpha \cos \alpha \cos \beta & \sin \alpha \cos \alpha \sin \beta & \cos ^2 \alpha\end{array}\right|\)

\(\left[R_1 \rightarrow(\sin \alpha) R_1, R_3 \rightarrow(\cos \alpha) R_3\right.\) and dividing \(\Delta\) by \(\left.(\sin \alpha \cos \alpha)\right]\)

\(=\frac{1}{\sin \alpha \cos \alpha} \cdot\left|\begin{array}{ccc}0 & 0 & -1 \\ -\sin \beta & \cos \beta & 0 \\ \sin \alpha \cos \alpha \cos \beta & \sin \alpha \cos \alpha \sin \beta & \cos ^2 \alpha\end{array}\right|\)

\(\left[R_1 \rightarrow\left(R_1-R_3\right)\right]\)

\(=\frac{1}{\sin \alpha \cos \alpha} \cdot(-1) \cdot\left|\begin{array}{cc}-\sin \beta & \cos \beta \\ \sin \alpha \cos \alpha \cos \beta & \sin \alpha \cos \alpha \sin \beta\end{array}\right|\)

\(=\frac{(\sin \alpha \cos \alpha)}{(\sin \alpha \cos \alpha)} \cdot(-1) \cdot\left|\begin{array}{cc}-\sin \beta & \cos \beta \\ \cos \beta & \sin \beta\end{array}\right|\)

[taking \(\sin \alpha \cos \alpha\) common from \(R_2\) ]

\(=(-1) \cdot\left[-\sin ^2 \beta-\cos ^2 \beta\right]=\left(\sin ^2 \beta+\cos ^2 \beta\right)=1\)

\(\Delta=1\)
Evaluate  \(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}a+b+2 c & a & b \\ c & b+c+2 a & b \\ c & a & c+a+2 b\end{array}\right|\) :

Let the value of the given determinant be \(\Delta\). Then,

\(\Delta=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}a+b+2 c & a & b \\ c & b+c+2 a & b \\ c & a & c+a+2 b\end{array}\right|\)

\(=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}a+b+c & -(a+b+c) & 0 \\ c & b+c+2 a & b \\ 0 & -(a+b+c) & (a+b+c)\end{array}\right|\left\{\begin{array}{l}\text { by } R_1 \rightarrow\left(R_1-R_2\right) \\ \text { and } R_3 \rightarrow\left(R_3-R_2\right)\end{array}\right\}\)

\(=(a+b+c)^2 \cdot\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & -1 & 0 \\ c & b+c+2 a & b \\ 0 & -1 & 1\end{array}\right|\)

[taking \((a+b+c)\) common from each one of \(R_1\) and \(R_3\) ]

\(=(a+b+c)^2 \cdot\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & b+2 c+2 a & b \\ 0 & -1 & 1\end{array}\right| \quad\left[R_2 \rightarrow R_2-c R_1\right]\)

\(=(a+b+c)^2 \cdot 1 \cdot\left|\begin{array}{cc}b+2 c+2 a & b \\ -1 & 1\end{array}\right| \quad\) [expanded by \(\left.C_1\right]\)

\(=(a+b+c)^2 \cdot(b+2 c+2 a+b)=2(a+b+c)^3\)

\(\Delta=2(a+b+c)^3\)
Evaluate \(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}a & b & c \\ a-b & b-c & c-a \\ b+c & c+a & a+b\end{array}\right|\) :

Let the value of the given determinant be \(\Delta\). Then,

\(\Delta=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}a & b & c \\ a-b & b-c & c-a \\ b+c & c+a & a+b\end{array}\right|\)

\(=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}a+b+c & b & c \\ 0 & b-c & c-a \\ 2(a+b+c) & c+a & a+b\end{array}\right| \quad\left[C_1 \rightarrow\left(C_1+C_2+C_3\right)\right]\)

\(=(a+b+c) \cdot\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & b & c \\ 0 & b-c & c-a \\ 2 & c+a & a+b\end{array}\right|\) \(\left[\right.\) taking \((a+b+c)\) common from \(\left.C_1\right]\)

\(=(a+b+c) \cdot\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & b & c \\ 0 & b-c & c-a \\ 0 & c+a-2 b & a+b-2 c\end{array}\right| \quad\left[R_3 \rightarrow R_3-2 R_1\right]\)

\(=(a+b+c) \cdot 1 \cdot\left|\begin{array}{cc}b-c & c-a \\ c+a-2 b & a+b-2 c\end{array}\right| \quad\) [expanded by \(\left.C_1\right]\)

\(=(a+b+c) \cdot\left|\begin{array}{ll}b-c & c-a \\ a-b & b-c\end{array}\right| \quad\left[R_2 \rightarrow R_2+R_1\right]\)

\(=(a+b+c) \cdot\left[(b-c)^2-(a-b)(c-a)\right]\)

\(=(a+b+c)\left(a^2+b^2+c^2-a b-b c-c a\right)\)

\(=\left(a^3+b^3+c^3-3 a b c\right)\)

\(\Delta=\left(a^3+b^3+c^3-3 a b c\right)\).
Evaluate \(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & a & bc \\ 1 & b & ca \\ 1 & c & ab \end{array}\right|\):

Given,

\(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & a & bc \\ 1 & b & ca \\ 1 & c & ab \end{array}\right|\)

Let, \(\Delta=\left|\begin{array}{lll}1 & a & bc \\ 1 & b & ca \\ 1 & c & ab \end{array}\right|\)

Now by applying row operation, \(R_2 \rightarrow R_2-R_1\) and \(R_3 \rightarrow R_3-R_1\) we get,

\(\Rightarrow \Delta=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & a & bc \\ 0 & b - a & ca - bc \\ 0 & c - a & ab - bc \end{array}\right|\)

\(=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & a & bc \\ 0 & b - a & c ( a - b ) \\ 0 & c - a & b ( a - c )\end{array}\right|\)

Taking \((a-b)\) and \((a-c)\) common we get,

\(\Rightarrow \Delta=( a - b )( a - c )\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & a & bc \\ 0 & -1 & c \\ 0 & -1 & b \end{array}\right|\)

So, \(\Delta=(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)\)
