Let the pairs \(\vec{a}, \vec{b}\) and \(\vec{c}, \vec{d}\) each determine a plane, then the planes are parallel if:

\(\vec{a} \times \vec{b}\) is a vector perpendicular to the plane containing \(\vec{a}\) and \(\vec{b}\).

Similarly, \(\vec{c} \times \vec{d}\) is a vector perpendicular to the plane containing \(\vec{c}\) and \(\overrightarrow{ d }\).

Thus, the two planes will be parallel if their normals, i.e., \(\vec{a} \times \vec{b}\) and \(\vec{c} \times \vec{d}\), are parallel.

Thus,

\((\vec{a} \times \vec{b}) \times(\vec{c} \times \vec{d})=\overrightarrow{0}\)
If one point on the vector \(2 i-4 j-k\) is \((2,1,3)\), the other point is?

Let the other point on the vector \(2 i-4 j-k\) be \((x, y, z)\).

Given point on the vector is \((2,1,3)\).

Thus the vector is represented as

\((2,-4,-1)=(x, y, z)-(2,1,3)\)

\((2,-4,-1)=(x-2, y-1, z-3)\)

Equating the corresponding points we get \(2=x-2,-4=y-\) \(1,-1=z-3\)

\(\Rightarrow x =4, y =-3, z =2\)

So the other point on the vector is \((4,-3,2)\).
If vectors \(i+2 j+2 k\) is rotated through an angle of \(90^{\circ}\) so as to cross the positive direction of \(y\)-axis, then the vector in the new position is:

Let the new position of the vector be \(OP ^{\prime}=x i+y j+z k\). As \(OP\) is making \(90^{\circ}\) with \(OP ^{\prime}\).

So \((x i+y j+z k) \cdot(i+2 j+2 k)=0 \Rightarrow x+2 y+2 z=0-----(1)\)

Also \(|\overrightarrow{O P}|=|\overrightarrow{OP^{\prime}|}\)

\(x^2+y^2+z^2=9-----(2)\)

Now if we say that the vector moves in such a way that it touches the \(y\) axis then we (perhaps) may assume that it moves in the plane determined by \(i\) and \(i+2 j+2 k\), the vector itself. A normal vector to this plane is \(j \times( i +2 j +2 k )=2 i - k\).

The equation of such a plane is \(2 x =z\).

So we have the following equation from (1) and (2)

\(5 x +2 y =0\)

and \(5 x^2+y^2=9\)

From here,

\(x=\pm \frac{2}{\sqrt{5}}\)

\(y=\pm \sqrt{5}\)

\(z=\pm \frac{4}{\sqrt{5}}\)

So the two vectors are \(O P=\frac{2}{\sqrt{5}} i-\sqrt{5} j+\frac{4}{\sqrt{5}} k\)

and \(O P^{\prime}=-\frac{2}{\sqrt{5}} i+\sqrt{5} j-\frac{4}{\sqrt{5}} k\)

\(EF GH\) is a rhombus such that the angle \(EF G\) is \(60^{\circ}\). The magnitude of vectors \(\overrightarrow{ FH }\) and \(\{m \overrightarrow{E G}\}\) are equal where \(m\) is a scalar. What is the value of \(m\)?

In triangle, \(FOG\),

\(\sin 30^{\circ}=\frac{O G}{a}\)

\(\Rightarrow OG = a \times \frac 12\)

\(EG =2 \times OG\)

\(=2 \times a \times \frac 12\)

\(= a \quad \ldots .(1)\)

In triangle, \(FOG\),

\(\cos 30^{\circ}= \frac{FO}{a}\)

\(\Rightarrow FO =\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \times a\)

\(FH =2 \times FO\)

\(=2 \times \frac{\sqrt 3}{2} \times a\)

\(=\sqrt{3} a \quad \ldots(2)\)

Divide (1) and (2)

\(\frac{EG}{FH} =\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\)

\(\Rightarrow FH =\sqrt{3} EG \quad(\because \overrightarrow{ FH }=\{ m \overrightarrow{ EG }\})\)

\(\therefore m=\sqrt{3}\)

If \(G\) and \(G'\) be the centroids of the triangles \(ABC\) and \(A'B' C'\) respectively, then \(\overrightarrow{ AA' }+\overrightarrow{ BB' }+\overrightarrow{ CC' }=?\)

Here we have been provided with two triangles \(A B C\) and \(A^{\prime} B^{\prime} C^{\prime}\) with their centroids as \(G\) and \(G ^{\prime}\) respectively. We have been asked to find the value of \(\overrightarrow{A A^{\prime}}+\overrightarrow{B B^{\prime}}+\overrightarrow{C C^{\prime}}\) in terms of \(\overrightarrow{G G^{\prime}}\).

Now, we know that if we write a vector in the form \(\overrightarrow{X Y}\) it denotes the relative position of vector \(Y\) with respect to vector \(X\). Head of this vector is towards point \(Y\) and the tail is towards point \(X\). If we have to write them as absolute position vectors that means position vector relative to the origin then we have \(\overrightarrow{X Y}=\vec{Y}-\vec{X}\). Using this concept we can write the relative position vectors representing the vertices of the triangle as:

(i) \(\overrightarrow{A A^{\prime}}=\overrightarrow{A^{\prime}}-\vec{A}\)

(ii) \(\overrightarrow{B B^{\prime}}=\overrightarrow{B^{\prime}}-\vec{B}\)

(iii) \(\overrightarrow{C C^{\prime}}=\overrightarrow{C^{\prime}}-\vec{C}\)

Adding the above three relations we get,

\(\Rightarrow \overrightarrow{A A^{\prime}}+\overrightarrow{B B^{\prime}}+\overrightarrow{C C^{\prime}}=\overrightarrow{A^{\prime}}-\vec{A}+\overrightarrow{B^{\prime}}-\vec{B}+\overrightarrow{C^{\prime}}-\vec{C}\)

Grouping the vectors representing the vertices of triangle \(A B C\) together and similarly the vectors representing the vertices of triangle \(A^{\prime} B^{\prime} C^{\prime}\) together we get,

\(\Rightarrow \overrightarrow{A A^{\prime}}+\overrightarrow{B B^{\prime}}+\overrightarrow{C C^{\prime}}=\left(\overrightarrow{A^{\prime}}+\overrightarrow{B^{\prime}}+\overrightarrow{C^{\prime}}\right) -(\vec{A}+\vec{B}+\vec{C})\)

The centroid of a triangle in vector form is given as \(\vec{G}=\frac{\vec{A}+\vec{B}+\vec{C}}{3}\) so using this relation for the triangle \(ABC\) and similarly the relation \(\overrightarrow{G^{\prime}}=\frac{\overrightarrow{A^{\prime}}+\overrightarrow{B^{\prime}}+\overrightarrow{C^{\prime}}}{3}\) for the triangle \(A^{\prime} B^{\prime} C^{\prime}\) we get,

\(\Rightarrow \overrightarrow{A A^{\prime}}+\overrightarrow{B B^{\prime}}+\overrightarrow{C C^{\prime}}=3 \overrightarrow{G^{\prime}}-3 \vec{G}\)

\(\Rightarrow \overrightarrow{A A^{\prime}}+\overrightarrow{B B^{\prime}}+\overrightarrow{C C^{\prime}}=3\left(\overrightarrow{G^{\prime}}-\vec{G}\right)\)

Converting \(\left(\overrightarrow{G^{\prime}}-\vec{G}\right)\) into relative position vector again we get,

\(\therefore \overrightarrow{A A^{\prime}}+\overrightarrow{B B^{\prime}}+\overrightarrow{C C^{\prime}}=3 \overrightarrow{G G^{\prime}}\)

The position vectors of two vertices and the centroid of a triangle are \(\vec{i}+\vec{j}, 2 \vec{i}-\vec{j}+\vec{k}\) and \(\vec{k}\) respectively, then the position vector of the third vertex of the triangle is:

Let the third vertex be \(C =\overrightarrow{x i}+y \vec{j}+z \vec{k}\) and \(A=(1,1,0), B=(2,-1,1), G =(0,0,1)\)

Hence \(G =\left(\frac{ x _1+ x _2+ x _3}{3}, \frac{ y _1+ y _2+ y _3}{3}, \frac{ z _1+ z _2+ z _3}{3}\right)\)

\((0,0,1)=\left(\frac{1+2+x}{3}, \frac{1-1+y}{3}, \frac{z+0+1}{3}\right)\)

\((0,0,1)=\left(\frac{x+3}{3}, \frac{y}{3}, \frac{z+1}{3}\right)\)

Hence \(\frac{ x +3}3=0\)

\(\Rightarrow x +3=0\)

\(x =-3\)

\(\frac{y}{3}=0\)

\(y=0\)

And \(\frac{z+1}{3}=1\)

\(z=2\)

Therefore, \(C =-3 \overrightarrow{ i }+2 \overrightarrow{ k }\).

If \(\vec{a}=2 \hat{i}-\hat{j}+\hat{k}, \vec{b}=\hat{i}+\hat{j}-2 \hat{k}\) and \(\vec{c}=\hat{i}+3 \hat{j}-\hat{k}\), find \(\lambda\) such that \(\vec{a}\) is perpendicular to \(\lambda \vec{b}+\vec{c}\):

We have

\(\lambda \vec{b}+\vec{c}=\lambda(\hat{i}+\hat{j}-2 \hat{k})+(\hat{i}+3 \hat{j}-\hat{k})\)

\(\Rightarrow \lambda \vec{b}+\vec{c}=(\lambda+1) \hat{i}+(\lambda+3) \hat{j}-(2 \lambda+1) \hat{k}\)

Now since \(\vec{a}\) is perpendicular to \(\lambda \vec{b}+\vec{c}\)

\(\vec{a} \cdot(\lambda \vec{b}+\vec{c})=0\)

\(\Rightarrow(2 \hat{i}-\hat{j}+\hat{k}) \cdot(\lambda \vec{b}+\vec{c})=0\)

\(\Rightarrow(2 \hat{i}-\hat{j}+\hat{k}) \cdot \lambda[(\hat{i}+\hat{j}-2 \hat{k})+(\hat{i}+3 \hat{j}-\hat{k})]=0\)

\(\Rightarrow 2(\lambda+1)-(\lambda+3)-(2 \lambda+1)=0\)

\(\Rightarrow \lambda=-2\)

Therefore the value of \(\lambda=-2\)

Two planes are perpendicular to each other, one of them contains vector \(\vec{a}\) and \(\vec{b}\), other contains \(\vec{c}\) and \(\vec{d}\) then \( (\vec{a} \times \vec{b}) \cdot(\vec{c} \times \vec{d})=?\)

Normal vector to plane \(\vec{a}, \vec{b}\) is given by, \(\vec{a} \times \vec{b}\)

Now for planes to be pependicular, the angle between their normal should be \(90^{\circ}\)

\(\Rightarrow(\vec{ a } \times \vec{ b }) \cdot(\vec{ c } \times \vec{ d })=|\vec{ a } \times \vec{ b }|| \vec{ c } \times \vec{ d } | \cos 90^{\circ}=0\)

Let \(\vec{b}\) and \(\vec{c}\) are non-collinear vectors. If \(\vec{a}\) is a vector such that \(\vec{a} \cdot(\vec{b}+\vec{c})=4\) and \(\vec{a} \times(\vec{b} \times \vec{c})=\left(x^2-2 x+6\right) \vec{b}+(\sin y) \vec{c}\), then \((x, y)\) lies on the line:

According to the definition of vector triple product.

And according to question

Now, on compairing

\(\vec{a} \cdot \vec{b}=-\sin y\)

\(\vec{a} \cdot(\vec{b}+\vec{c})=4\)

\(\vec{a} \cdot \vec{b}+\vec{a} \cdot \vec{c}=4\)

\(-\sin y+x^2-2 x+6=4\)

\( (x-1)^2+1=\sin y\)

Minimum value L.H.S. occurs when square term is 0 thus \(x -1=0\) that is \(x =1\) and this minimum value will be \((1-1)^2+1=1\) and the maximum value of \(\sin y\) is \(1\).

Thus,

\( (x-1)^2+1=\sin y\) is possible when \(x=1\) and \(y=\frac{\pi}{2}\)

\( (x, y)=\left(1, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)\)

There will be infinite lines on which \((x, y)=\left(1, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)\) will lie and \(x=1\) is one of them.
Given the points \(A(-2,3,4), B(3,2,5)\), \(C(1,-1,2)\) and \(D(3,2,-4)\). The projection of the vector \(\overrightarrow{A B}\) on the vector \(\overrightarrow{C D}\) is:

Now considering from the question we have \(A(-2,3,4), B(3,2,5), C(1,-1,2)\) and \(D(3,2,-4)\).

We know from the basic concept that the projection of the vector \(\overrightarrow{A B}\) on the vector \(\overrightarrow{C D}\) is given by the dot product of the directional ratios of both the lines divided by the length of \(\overrightarrow{C D}\).

The directional ratios of a line joining \(\left(x_1, y_1, z_1\right)\) and \(\left(x_2, y_2, z_2\right)\) is given as \(\left(x_2-x_1, y_2-y_1, z_2-z_1\right)\).

So here the directional ratio of \(\overrightarrow{A B}\) is given as

\( (3-(-2), 2-3,5-4)=(5,-1,1)\)

The directional ratio of \(\overrightarrow{C D}\) is given as

\((3-1,2-(-1),-4-(2) )=(2,3,-6\)

The dot product of the directional ratios of \(\overrightarrow{A B}\) and \(\overrightarrow{C D}\) that is

\((5,-1,1) \cdot(2,3,-6)=(10-3-6)=1\)

The magnitude of the line \(\overrightarrow{C D}\) is given as

\(\sqrt{(2)^2+(3)^2+(-6)^2}=\sqrt{4+9+36}\)

\(=\sqrt{49}=7\)

The projection of the vector \(\overrightarrow{A B}\) on the vector \( \overrightarrow{C D}\) is \(\frac{\overrightarrow{A B} \cdot \overrightarrow{C D}}{|\overrightarrow{C D}|}=\frac{1}{7}\)

\(=\overrightarrow{ SA }+\overrightarrow{2 SD }=\overrightarrow{ SA }+\overrightarrow{ AH }=\overrightarrow{ SH }\)

( \(\because H \cdot G : GS =2: 1\) where \(G\) is centroid )

\(\overrightarrow{ DM }=\) position vector of \(M -\) position vector of \(D\)

\(=\frac{|\vec{a}|^2-|\vec{p}|^2}{2}=\) \(0 \Rightarrow \overrightarrow{ DM } \perp \overrightarrow{ AP }\)

In order that linear programming techniques provide valid results:

Linear Programming: Linear programming is an important optimization (maximization or minimization) technique used in decision making in business and every - day life for obtaining the maximum or minimum values as required of linear expression, subjected to satisfy a certain number of given linear restrictions.

Linear programming problem (LPP): The linear programming problem is general calls for optimizing (maximizing/minimizing) a linear function of variables called the objective function subject to a set of linear equations and/or linear inequations called the constraints or restrictions.

The function which is to be optimized (maximized or minimized) is called the objective function.

The system of linear inequations (or equations) under which the objective function is to be optimized are called the constraints.

A primary requirement of an LPP is that both the objective function and all the constraints must be expressed in terms of linear equations and inequalities.

Consider the following Linear Programming Problem (LPP).

Maximise \(Z=x_{1}+2 x_{2}\)

Subject to:

\(x_{1} \leq 2\)

\(x_{2} \leq 2\)

\(x_{1}+x_{2} \leq 2\)

\(x_{1}, x_{2} \geq 0\) (i.e., +ve decision variables)

Given

Objective function

Maximize, \(Z=x_{1}+2 x_{2}\)

Constraints

\(x_{1} \leq 2 \)

\(x_{2} \leq 2 \)

\(x_{1}+x_{2} \leq 2 \)

Non neagative constarints

\(\mathrm{x}_{1}, \mathrm{x}_{2} \geq 0\)

The above equations can be written as,

\(\frac{x_{1}}{2} \leq 1 \)

\(\frac{x_{2}}{2} \leq 1 \)

\(\frac{x_{1}}{2}+\frac{x_{2}}{2} \leq 1\)

Plot the above equations on \(x_{1}-x_{2}\) graph and find out the solution space.


Now, find out the value of the objective function at every extreme point of solution space.

\(Z=x_{1}+2 x_{2}\)

\(Z_{0}=0+2 \times 0=0 \)

\(Z_{A}=0+2 \times 2=4 \)

\(Z_{B}=2+2 \times 0=2\)

Since the value of the objective function is maximum at \(A\). There \(A(0,2)\) is the optimal solution.

An aeroplane can carry a maximum of 200 passengers. A profit of ₹ 1000 is made on each executive class ticket and a profit of ₹ 600 is made on each economy class ticket. The airline reserves at least 20 seats for executive class. However, at least 4 times as many passengers prefer to travel by economy class than by the executive class. Determine how many tickets of each type must be sold in order to maximise the profit for the airline. What is the maximum profit?

Let the airline sell \(x\) tickets of executive class and \(y\) tickets of economy class.

The mathematical formulation of the given problem is as follows:

Maximize \(\mathrm{Z}=1000 \mathrm{x}+600 \mathrm{y}\),

subject to the constraints,

\(x+y \leq 200\) ...(i)

\(x \geq 20\) ...(ii)

\(y-4 x \geq 0\) ...(iii)

\(x, y \geq 0\) ...(iv)

The feasible region determined by the constraints is as follows:


From equation (i) and (iii):

 x + y \(\leq\) 200 
 x \(\leq\) 40
Put the value of x in equation (i):
y \(\leq\) 160

The corner points of the feasible region are \(A(20,80), B(40,160)\), and \(C(20,180)\).

The values of \(\mathrm{Z}\) at these corner points are as follows:

Corner PointZ= 1000x + 600y 
A (20,80)68000
B (40, 160)136000
C (20, 180)128000
The maximum value of \(\mathrm{Z}\) is 136000 at \((40,160)\).
Thus, 40 tickets of executive class and 160 tickets of economy class should be sold to maximize the profit and the maximum profit is ₹ 136000 .

Corner pointZ=600x+400y

Subject to:

\(100 \geq 2 X+Y\) \(\dots\) (iii)

\( X \geq 0, Y \geq 0\) \(\dots\) (iv)

From equation (ii) and (iii)

\(140 \geq 2 X+2Y\)

\(70 \geq X+Y\) \(\dots\) (v)

Multiply equation (v) with 3 then substract it from equation (ii), we get,

\(30 \geq X\)

Put value of \(X\) in equation (ii)

\(240 \geq 120+3Y\)

\(40 \geq Y\)

To find the optimal solution to this LP using the graphical method we first identify the region of feasible solutions and the corner points of the of the feasible region. The graph for this is plotted below:

In this, the corner points are \((0,0),(50,0)\), \((30,40)\) and \((0,80)\). Testing these corner points on \(P=7 X+5 Y\) gives:


 Corner Point profit
A \((0,0)\)\( 0\)
B \((50,0)\)\(350\)
C \((30,40)\)\(410\)
D \((0,80)\)\(400\)
Because the point \((30,40)\) produces the highest profit we conclude that point C \((30, 40)\) will yield the maximum profit of \(410\).

The volume of a spherical balloon is increasing at the rate of \(2 \mathrm{~cm}^3 / \mathrm{sec}\). When its radius is \(4 \mathrm{~cm}\), the rate of change of its surface area (in \(\mathrm{cm}^2 / \mathrm{sec}\) ) is:

Given: The volume of a spherical balloon is increasing at the rate of 2 \({cm}^3 / {sec}\).

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d V}{d t}=2 {~cm}^3 / {sec}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{4}{3} \pi r^3\right)=2\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{4}{3} \pi \frac{d}{d t}\left(r^3\right)=2\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{4}{3} \pi\left(3 r^2\right) \frac{d r}{d t}=2\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d r}{d t}=\frac{1}{2 \pi r^2}\).....(1)

The surface area of sphere \(=4 \pi r^2\)

The rate of change of its surface area \(=\frac{d}{d t}\left(4 \pi r^2\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow\) The rate of change of its surface area \(=4 \pi(2 r) \frac{d r}{d t}\)

Putting value from (1),

\(\Rightarrow\) The rate of change of its surface area \(=8 \pi r . \frac{1}{2 \pi r^2}=\frac{4}{r}\)

When \({r}=4 {~cm}\),

The rate of change of its surface area \(=\frac{4}{4}=1\)
If \(\mathrm{V}=\frac{4}{3} \pi \mathrm{r}^3\) at what rate is \(\mathrm{V}\) increasing in cubic units when \(\mathrm{r}=10\) and \(\frac{\mathrm{dr}}{\mathrm{dt}}=0.01\)

Given that

\(\mathrm{V}=\frac{4}{3} \pi \mathrm{r}^3\)

\(\frac{d V}{d t}=\frac{4}{3} \pi \frac{d}{d r} r^3\)

\(\frac{d V}{d t}=\frac{4}{3} \pi \times 3 r^2 \times \frac{d r}{d t}\)

\(\frac{d V}{d t}=4 \pi r^2 \times \frac{d r}{d t}\)

According to the question,

At \(\mathrm{r}=10, \frac{\mathrm{dr}}{\mathrm{dt}}=0.01\)

\(\frac{d V}{d t}=4 \pi(10)^2 \times 0.01\)

\(\therefore \frac{d V}{d t}=4 \pi\)
Find the points on the curve \(y=x^3-3 x+12\) at which the tangent is perpendicular to the straight line \(y=\frac{-x}{9}\).

Let's take slope of tangent is \(m\).

Given that a line \(y=\frac{-x}{9}\)

By comparing with standard equation of line, \(y=m x+c\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Slope of line \(=\frac{-1}{9}\)

Given the tangent is perpendicular to the straight line.

\(\therefore\) Slope of tangent:

\(\Rightarrow {m} \times(\frac{-1}{9})=-1\)

\(\Rightarrow {m}=9 \quad \ldots .(1)\)

From the given curve equation,

\(\Rightarrow {y}={x}^3-3 {x}+12\)

Differentiate with respect to \(x\), we get

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d y}{d x}=3 x^2-3 \quad \ldots .(2)\)

We know that slope \(={m}=\frac{{dy}}{{dx}}\)

\(\therefore 3 x^2-3=9\)

\(\Rightarrow 3 x^2=12\)

\(\Rightarrow x^2=\frac{12}{3}\)

\(\Rightarrow x^2=4\)

\(\Rightarrow x= \pm 2\)

So by putting \({x}=2\) and \({x}=-2\) in curve equation we will get \({y}\),

While \({x}=2\)

\(\Rightarrow {y}=(2)^3-32+12\)

\(\Rightarrow {y}=14\)

So point is \((2,14)\)

While \(x=-2\)

\(\Rightarrow {y}=(-2)^3-3(-2)+12\)

\(\Rightarrow {y}=10\)

So point is \((-2,10)\)
The point(s) on the curve \(y=x^3-11 x+5\) at which the tangent is \(y=x-11\) is/are:

Given, the curve \(y=x^3-11 x+5---(1)\)

The slope of the tangent \(=\frac{d y}{d x}--(2)\)

Differentiate equation (1) w.r.t. x, we have

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d y}{d x}=3 x^2-11\)

The tangent to the curves is \(y=x-11--(3)\)

The slope of the tangent \(=1\)

From equation (2),

\(\therefore \frac{d y}{d x}=1\)

\(\Rightarrow 3 x^2-11=1\)

\(\Rightarrow 3 x^2=12\)

\(\Rightarrow x^2=4\)

\(\Rightarrow x= \pm 2\)

From equation (1), at \(x=2, y=2^3-11 \times 2+5=-9\) and at \(x=-2, y=(-2)^3-11 \times(-2)+5=19\)

The points are \((2,-9)\) and \((-2,19)\).

These points should satisfy the equation of tangent also.

Substitute \(x=2\) and \(y=-9\) in the equation (3), we have

\(\Rightarrow-9=2-11\)

\(\Rightarrow-9=-9\)

Therefore, the point \((2,-9)\) lies on the tangent.

Now, substitute \(x=-2\) and \(y=19\) in the equation (3), we have

\(\Rightarrow 19 \neq-2-11\)

\(\Rightarrow 19 \neq-13\)

The point \((-2,19)\) does not lie on the tangent.

Therefore, the point is \((2,-9)\).
The minimum value of the function \(f(x)=2 x^2-\ln |x|\), when \(x \geq 1\) is:

Given, \(f(x)=2 x^2-\ln |x|\)

Differentiating with respect to \(x\) :

\(\Rightarrow {f}^{\prime}({x})=4 {x}-\frac{1}{{x}}\)

To find the critical point, put \(f(x)=0\).

\(\Rightarrow 4 {x}-\frac{1}{{x}}=0\)

\(\Rightarrow 4 {x}=\frac{1}{{x}}\)

\(\Rightarrow 4 {x}^2=1\)

\(\Rightarrow {x}^2=\frac{1}{4}\)

\(\Rightarrow {x}= \pm \frac{1}{2}\)

Given \(x \geq 1\)

\(\therefore\) Minimum values of \({f}({x})={f}(1)\)

\(=2 \times 1^2-\ln 1=2-0\)

\(=2\)

Therefore the minimum value of \(f(x)\) is 2.
The function \(f(x)=x^3-4 x^2+4 x+3\) defined on \([-1,3]\) has:

Given function \(f(x)=x^3-4 x^2+4 x+3\).

\(f(x)=3 x^2-8 x+4\)

For critical point, put \(f^{\prime}(x)=0\)

\(\Rightarrow 3 x^2-8 x+4=0\)

\(\Rightarrow 3 x^2-6 x-2 x+4=0\)

\(\Rightarrow 3 x(x-2)-2(x-2)=0\)

\(\Rightarrow(3 x-2)(x-2)=0\)

\(\Rightarrow x=2 \text { or } x=\frac{2}{3}\)

Now \({f}^{\prime}({x})=6 {x}-8\)

\(f^{\prime \prime}\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)=-4\)

\(f^{\prime \prime}(2)=12-8=4\) which is greater than zero.

hence \(f(x)\) has local minima at \(x=2\).

\(\therefore\) Minimum value is \(\mathrm{f}(2)=2^3-4 \times 2^2+4 \times 2+3\)

\(f(2)=8-16+8+3\)

\(\Rightarrow f(2)=3\)

Now checking \({f}({x})\) at border points \({x}=-1\) and \({x}=3\)

\(f(-1)=(-1)^3-4 \times(-1)^2+4 \times(-1)+3\)

\(f(-1)=-1-4-4+3=-6\)

\(\Rightarrow f(-1)=-6\)

Find the interval in which the function \(f ( x )= x +\frac{1}{ x }\) is strictly increasing?

Given: \(f ( x )= x +\frac{1}{ x }\)

As we know that for a strictly increasing function \(f^{\prime}(x)>0\) for all \(x \in(a, b)\) 

Let's find \(f^{\prime}(x)\)

As we know that, \(\frac{d}{d x}\{f(x) \pm g(x)\}=\frac{d\{f(x)\}}{d x} \pm \frac{d\{g(x)\}}{d x}\)

\( \Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)=1-\frac{1}{x^2}=\frac{x^2-1}{x^2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{x^2-1}{x^2}>0 \text {------- }\left(\because f(x) \text { is a strictly increasing function }\right)\)

\( \Rightarrow x^2-1>0\)

\( \Rightarrow(x-1) \cdot(x+1)>0 \)

\(\Rightarrow x<-1 \text { or } x>1\)

\( \Rightarrow x \in(-\infty,-1) \cup(1, \infty)\)

Hence, the interval in which the given function \(f(x)\) is strictly increasing is: \((-\infty,-1) \cup(1, \infty)\)
Find the interval in which the function \(f(x)=\log (1+x)-\frac{x}{(1+x)}\) is decreasing?

Given: \(f(x)=\log (1+x)-\frac{x}{(1+x)}\)

Here we have to find the interval in which \(f(x)\) is decreasing.

Let's first calculate \(f^{\prime}(x)\)

As we know that \(\frac{d}{d x}\{f(x) \pm g(x)\}=\frac{d\{f(x)\}}{d x} \pm \frac{d\{g(x)\}}{d x}, \frac{d(\log x)}{d x}=\frac{1}{x}\), for \(x>0\) and \(\frac{d}{d x}\left[\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}\right]=\frac{g(x) \cdot \frac{d(f(x))}{d x}-f(x) \cdot \frac{d(g(x))}{d x}}{[g(x)]^2}\)

\(\Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)=\left\{\frac{1}{1+x}-\frac{(1+x) \cdot 1-x \cdot 1}{(1+x)^2}\right\}=\frac{x}{(1+x)^2}\)

As we know that for a decreasing function say \(f(x)\) we have \(f^{\prime}(x) \leq 0\)

\( \Rightarrow \frac{x}{(1+x)^2} \leq 0 \)

\( \Rightarrow x \leq 0--\left(\because(1+ x )^2 \geq 0\right)\)

Hence, the given function is decreasing for the interval \((-\infty, 0]\)
Find the interval in which the function \(f(x)=(x+2) e^{-x}\) is decreasing ?

Given: \(f(x)=(x+2) e^{-x}\)

Here we have to find the interval in which \(f(x)\) is decreasing.

Let's first calculate \(f^{\prime}(x)\)

As we know that,

As we know that, \(\frac{d}{d x}[f(x) \cdot g(x)]=f(x) \cdot \frac{d\{g(x)\}}{d x}+g(x) \cdot \frac{d\{f(x)\}}{d x}\)

\(\Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)=(x+2) \cdot \frac{d\left(e^{-x}\right)}{d x}+e^{-x} \cdot \frac{d(x+2)}{d x}\)

As we know that, \(\frac{d\left(e^{a x}\right)}{d x}=a \cdot e^{a x}\)

\( \Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)=-(x+2) \cdot e^{-x}+e^{-x} \cdot 1\)

\( \Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)=-(x+1) \cdot e^{-x}\)

As we know that for a decreasing function say \(f(x)\) we have \(f^{\prime}(x) \leq 0\).

\( \Rightarrow-(x+1) \cdot e^{-x} \leq 0 \)

\( \Rightarrow(x+1) \cdot e^{-x} \geq 0 \)

\( \Rightarrow x+1 \geq 0-\cdots\left(\because e^{-x}>0\right) \)

\( \Rightarrow x \geq-1\)

Hence, the interval in which the given function is decreasing is \([-1, \infty\) )
Which of the following is true regarding the function \(f(x)=\tan ^{-1}(\cos x+\sin x)\) ?
\(f(x)\) is a strictly decreasing function in \((0, \frac{\pi }{ 4})\)
\(f(x)\) is neither strictly increasing nor decreasing in \((0, \frac{\pi }{ 4})\)
\(f(x)\) is a strictly increasing function in \((0, \frac{\pi }{ 4})\)

Given: \(f(x)=\tan ^{-1}(\cos x+\sin x)\)

Let's find out \(f^{\prime}(x)\)

As we know that, \(\frac{d\left(\tan ^{-1} x\right)}{d x}=\frac{1}{1+x^2}\) and according to chain rule \(\frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{d y}{d v} \cdot \frac{d v}{d x}\)

\( \Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{1}{1+(\cos x+\sin x)^2} \cdot \frac{d(\cos x+\sin x)}{d x}\)

\( \Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{\cos x-\sin x}{2+\sin 2 x}\)

Now when \(0<x<\frac{\pi }{ 4}\), we have \(\cos x>\sin x\) and \(\sin 2 x>0\)

\( \Rightarrow \cos x -\sin x >0 \) and \( 2+2 \sin 2 x >0 \)

\( \Rightarrow f ^{\prime}( x )>0 \forall x \in(0, \frac{\pi }{ 4})\)

As we know that for a strictly increasing function \(f^{\prime}(x)>0\) for all \(x \in(a, b)\)

So, the given function \(f(x)\) is a strictly increasing function on \((0, \frac{\pi }{ 4})\).
Which of the following is true regarding the function \(f(x)=\log (\sin x)\)?
\(f(x)\) is neither strictly increasing nor strictly decreasing function on \((0, \frac{\pi }{ 2})\)

Given: \(f(x)=\log (\sin x)\)

Let's examine the function \(f(x)\) on the interval \((0, \frac{\pi }{ 2})\)

So, first let's calculate \(f ^{\prime}( x )\)

\(\Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{1}{\sin x} \cdot \frac{d(\sin x)}{d x}=\cot x\)

As we know that \(\cot x>0 \forall x \in(0, \frac{ \pi }{ 2})\)

\(\Rightarrow f ^{\prime}( x )>0 \forall x \in(0, \frac{\pi }{ 2})\)

As we know that for a strictly increasing function \(f ^{\prime}( x )>0\) for all \(x \in( a , b )\)

So, the given function \(f ( x )\) is a strictly increasing function on \((0, \frac{\pi }{2})\).

\(\therefore\) Option (A) is true

Now let's the function \(f(x)\) on the interval \((\frac{\pi }{ 2}, \pi)\)

As we know that, \(f ^{\prime}( x )=\cot x\) and \(\cot x <0 \forall x \in(\frac{\pi }{ 2}, \pi)\)

\(\Rightarrow f ^{\prime}( x )<0 \forall x \in(\frac{\pi }{ 2}, \pi)\)

As we know that for a strictly decreasing function \(f ^{\prime}( x )<0\) for all \(x \in( a , b )\)

So, the given function \(f(x)\) is a strictly decreasing function on \((\frac{\pi }{ 2}, \pi)\)

\(\therefore\) Option (B) is true.

\(\text { Here, } f ( x )=\frac{ x ^2}{ e ^{ x }}\)

\( \therefore f ^{\prime}( x )=\frac{ d }{ dx }\left(\frac{ x ^2}{ e ^{ x }}\right) \)

\(=\frac{2 x \left( e ^{ x }\right)- x ^2\left( e ^{ x }\right)}{\left( e ^{ x }\right)^2}\)

\( \Rightarrow f ^{\prime}( x )=\frac{2 x - x ^2}{ e ^{ x }}\)

Now, for \(f(x)\) to be monotonically increasing function \(f^{\prime}(x)\) should be greater than 0.

\( \therefore \frac{2 x - x ^2}{ e ^{ x }}>0 \)

\( \Rightarrow\left(2 x - x ^2\right)>0 \)

\( \Rightarrow x (2- x )>0 \)

\( \Rightarrow x >0\) OR \(x <2\)

\( \therefore 0< x <2\)
If \(f(x)\) is an increasing function and \(g(x)\) is a decreasing function such that \(\operatorname{gof}(x)\) is defined, then \(\operatorname{gof}(x)\) will be:

Given: \(f(x)\) is an increasing function and \(g(x)\) is a decreasing function

Let \(h(x)=g \circ f(x)=g(f(x))\)

What is the angle between the below given lines?

\(\overrightarrow{\mathbf{r}}=3 \hat{\mathbf{i}}+\hat{\mathbf{j}}-2 \hat{\mathbf{k}}+\lambda(\hat{\mathbf{i}} - \hat{\mathbf{j}}-2 \hat{\mathbf{k}})\) and \(\overrightarrow{\mathbf{r}}=3 \hat{\mathbf{i}}-\hat{\mathbf{j}}-56 \hat{\mathbf{k}}+\mu(3 \hat{\mathbf{i}}-5 \hat{\mathbf{j}}-4 \hat{\mathbf{k}})\)
Find the angle between the lines \( \vec{r}=3 i+2 j-4 k+\lambda(i+2 j+2 k) \) and \(\vec{r}=(5 j-2 k)+\mu(3 i+2 j+6 k)\).

Given,

\(    \vec{r}=3 i+2 j-4 k+\lambda(i+2 j+2 k) \)

\(    \vec{r}=(5 j-2 k)+\mu(3 i+2 j+6 k)     \)

We know that, angle between \(r=a_1+\lambda b_1\) and \(r=a_2+\lambda b_2\) is given by,

\(\cos \theta=\frac{\overrightarrow{b_1} \cdot \overrightarrow{b_2}}{\left|\overrightarrow{b_1}\right|\left|\overrightarrow{b_1}\right|}\)

\(\overrightarrow{b_1}=1+2 j+2 k\) and \(\overrightarrow{b_2}=3 i+2 j+6 k\) respectively.

\(=\frac{(i+2 j+2 k)(3 i+2 j+6 k)}{|i+2 j+2 k||3 i+2 j+6 k|}\)

\(=\frac{3+4+12}{\sqrt{1+4+4} \sqrt{9+4+36}}\)

\(=\frac{19}{21}\)

\(\Rightarrow \theta=\cos ^{-1}\left(\frac{19}{21}\right)\)
Distance of the plane \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{r}} \cdot(2 \hat{\mathrm{i}}-\hat{\mathrm{j}}+2 \hat{\mathrm{k}})=12\), from the origin is:

The plane is given as, \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{r}} \cdot(2 \hat{\mathrm{i}}-\hat{\mathrm{j}}+2 \hat{\mathrm{k}})=12\)

We know that \(\vec{r}=x \hat{i}+y \hat{j}+z \hat{k}\)

We can write the equation of the plane in general form as,

\(2 x-y+2 z-12=0\)......(1)

Now, to get the normal form of a plane given in general form as,

\(A x+B y+C z+D=0\) where \(D \neq 0\).............(2)

Distance between plane and origin is given as:

\(p=-\frac{-D}{|\vec{n}|}\)

we have to divide the equation (1) by \(|\vec{n}|\), where \(\vec{n}\) is the normal vector given as,

\(\vec{n}=(2 \hat{\mathrm{i}}-\hat{\mathrm{j}}+2 \hat{\mathrm{k}})\)

Now, \(|\vec{n}|=(2 \hat{\mathrm{i}}-\hat{\mathrm{j}}+2 \hat{\mathrm{k}})\)

\(|\vec{n}|=\sqrt{2^2+(-1)^2+(2)^2}=3\)

Comparing equation (1) with equation (2), we get,

\(D=-12\)

\(p=-\frac{-D}{|\vec{n}|}\)

\(p=-\frac{-12}{3}=4\)

Let \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) are the lengths of the perpendiculars from the points \((2,3,-5)\) and \((3,1,1)\) respectively from the plane \(x+2 y-2 z-9=0\), then \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) are the roots of which equation?

Perpendicular Distance of a Point from a Plane

Let us consider a plane given by the Cartesian equation,

\(Ax+By+Cz=d\) and a point whose coordinate is,

\(\left(x_1, y_1, z_1\right)\).

Then the distance between the point and the plane is given by:

\(\left|\frac{A x_1+B y_1+C z_1-d}{\sqrt{A^2+B^2+C^2}}\right|\)

Quadratic equation with roots \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) :

Quadratic equation with roots \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) is given by:

\((x-\alpha)(x-\beta)=0\)

We know that the distance between the point and the plane is given by

\(\left|\frac{A x_1+B y_1+C z_1-d}{\sqrt{A^2+B^2+C^2}}\right|\)

So, the distance of the point \((2,3,-5)\) from the given plane

\(\alpha=\left|\frac{2 \times 1+2 \times 3+(-2) \times(-5)-9}{\sqrt{1^2+(-2)^2+(2)^2}}\right|=3\)

Similarly, the distance of the point \((3,1,1)\) from the given plane

\(\beta=\left|\frac{3 \times 1+2 \times 1+(-2) \times 1-9}{\sqrt{1^2+(-2)^2+(2)^2}}\right|=2\)

Therefore, quadratic equation with roots 3 & 2 will be

\((x-2)(x-3)=0\)

\(\Rightarrow x^2-3 x-2 x+6=0\)

\(\Rightarrow x^2-5 x+6=0\)
What is the distance of the point \((2,3,4)\) from the plane \(3 x-6 y+2 z+11=0\) ?

Perpendicular distance of a point from a plane:

Let us consider a plane given by a cartesian equation,

\(A x+B y+C z=d\), and a point whose coordinates are \(\left(\mathrm{x}_1, \mathrm{y}_1, \mathrm{z}_1\right)\).

So,

Distance \(=\left|\frac{A x_1+B y_1+C z_1-d}{\sqrt{A^2+B^2+C^2}}\right|\)

We have to find the distance of point \((2,3,4)\) from the plane \(3 x-6 y+2 z+11=0\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Distance \(=\left|\frac{3 \times 2+(-6) \times 3+2 \times 4+11}{\sqrt{3^2+(-6)^2+2^2}}\right|\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Distance \(=\left|\frac{6-18+8+11}{\sqrt{9+36+4}}\right|\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Distance \(=\left|\frac{7}{\sqrt{49}}\right|\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Distance \(=1\)

So, The distance of the point \((2,3,4)\) from the plane \(3 x-6 y+2 z+11=0\) is 1 unit.
Find the possible value of \(k\) for which the distance between two plane \(6 x+\) \(3 y-2 z+k=0\) and \(3 x+1.5 y-z+2=0\) is \(5\).

The distance between two parallel planes \(a x+b y+c z+d_1=0\) and \(a x+b y+c z+d_2=0\) is given by: \(D=\left|\frac{d_1-d_2}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}}\right|\)

Given,

\(6 x+3 y-2 z+k=0\) and \(3 x+1.5 y-z+2=0\) are two planes and the shortest distance between them is 5 .

The equation of plane \(3 x+1.5 y-z+2=0\) can be re-written as: \(6 x+3 y-2 z+4=0\) by multiplying both sides of the equation \(3 x+1.5 y-z+2=0\) by 2 .

As we can see that, the given planes \(6 x+3 y-2 z+k=0\) and \(6 x+3 y-2 z+4=0\) are parallel.

As we know that, the distance between two parallel planes \(a x+b y+c z+d_1=0\) and \(a x\) \(+\) by \(+\mathrm{cz}+\mathrm{d}_2=0\) is given by:

\(D=\left|\frac{d_1-d_2}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}}\right|\)

Here, \(d_1=k, d_2=4, a=6, b=3, c=-2\) and \(D=5\).

\(\Rightarrow D=\left|\frac{d_1-d_2}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}}\right|\)

\(\Rightarrow 5=\left|\frac{k-4}{\sqrt{6^2+3^2+(-2)^2}}\right|\)

\(\Rightarrow 5=\left|\frac{k-4}{\sqrt{36+9+4}}\right|\)

\(\Rightarrow 5 \times 7=|\mathrm{k}-4|\)

Case \(-1\) : If \(k \geq 4\) then \(k-4=35 \Rightarrow k=39\)

Case-2: If \(k<4\) then \(-k+4=35 \Rightarrow k=-31\)

So, \(k=39,-31\)
Find the distance between the planes \(2 x+y-2 z+6=0\) and \(4 x+2 y-4 z-6=\) \(0\) .

Given,

\(2 x+y-2 z+6=0\) and \(4 x+2 y-4 z-6=0\) are two planes.

Here, we can rewrite the equation of plane \(2 x+y-2 z+6=0\) as \(4 x+2 y-4 z+12=0\) by multiplying both the sides of \(2 x+y-2 z+6=0\) with \(2\).

As we can see that, the plane \(4 x+2 y-4 z+12=0\) and \(4 x+2 y-4 z-6=0\) are parallel planes.

As we know that, the distance between two parallel planes \(a x+b y+c z+d_1=0\) and ax \(+\) by \(+\mathrm{cz}+\mathrm{d}_2=0\) is given by: \(D=\left|\frac{d_1-d_2}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}}\right|\)

Here, \(a=4, b=2, c=-4, d_1=12\) and \(d_2=-6\).

\(\Rightarrow D=\left|\frac{d_1-d_2}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}}\right|\)

\(\Rightarrow D=\left|\frac{12-(-6)}{\sqrt{4^2+2^2+(-4)^2}}\right|\)

The straight lines whose direction cosines satisfy: \(a l+b m+c n=0\) and \(f m n+g n l+h l m=0\) are perpendicular if:

Given,

\(a l+b m+c n=0\) .....(1)

\(f{m n}+g n l+h l m=0\).....(2)

From the equation (1), we get

\(n=-\frac{(a l+b m)}{c}\)

Putting the value of n inn equation (1), we get

\(\Rightarrow fm\left\{\frac{-(a l+b m)}{c}\right\}+g l\left\{-\frac{(a l+b m)}{c}\right\}+h l m=0\)

\(\Rightarrow f m(a l+b m)+g l(a l+b m)-h l m c=0\)

\(\Rightarrow a f l m+b m^2+a g l^2+b g l m-h l m c=0\)

\(\Rightarrow a g l^2+(a f+b g-c h) l m+b fm^2=0\)

Divide both sides by \(m^2\), we get

Equation (3) is quadratic equation in \(\frac lm\)

Then, the roots of equation (3) be \(\frac{l_1}{m_1}\) and \(\frac{l_2}{m_2}\).

where,

\(\frac{l_1}{m_1} \times \frac{l_2}{m_2}=\frac{b f}{a g}=\frac{ \frac f  a}{\frac g  b}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{l_1 l_2}{\frac f  a}=\frac{m_1 m_2}{\frac g  b}\)

By symmetricity of l, m and n, we get

\(\Rightarrow \frac{l_1 l_2}{\frac f  a}=\frac{m_1 m_2}{\frac g  b}=\frac{n_1 n_2}{\frac h  c}=K\)

\(\Rightarrow l_1 l_2=\left(\frac{f}{a}\right)^k, m_1 m_2=\left(\frac{g}{b}\right)^k, n_1 n_2=\left(\frac{h}{c}\right)^k\)

For lines to be perpendicular,

\(l_1 l_2+m_1 m_2+n_1 n_2=0\)

\(\left(\frac{f}{a}\right) k+\left(\frac{g}{b}\right)k+\left(\frac{h}{c}\right) k=0\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{f}{a}+\frac{g}{b}+\frac{h}{c}=0\)

Find the general solution of given differential equation \(\frac{x d y}{d x}+3 y=4 x^3 ?\)

Given that,

\(\Rightarrow \frac{ xdy }{ dx }+3 y =4 x ^3\)

Now,

\(\Rightarrow \frac{ dy }{ dx }+\frac{3 y }{ x }=4 x ^2\)

By comparing with \(\frac{ dy }{ dx }+ Py = Q\)

\( \Rightarrow P=\frac{3 } x \text { and } Q=4 x^2 \)

\( \Rightarrow \text { I.F. }=e^{\int P d x}=e^{\int \frac{3}{x} d x} \)

\(\Rightarrow \text { I.F. }=e^{3 \ln x} \)

\( \Rightarrow \text { I.F. }=e^{\ln x^3}\)

\( \Rightarrow \text { I.F. }=x^3\left(\because e^{\ln x}=x\right)\)

Now general solution will be,

\( \Rightarrow y \cdot( I \cdot F \cdot)=\int( Q \cdot( I \cdot F \cdot)) dx + c \)

\( \Rightarrow y \cdot\left( x ^3\right)=\int\left(4 x ^2 \cdot\left( x ^3\right)\right) dx + c\)

Integrating factor of \(\left(1-x^2\right) \frac{d y}{d x}-x y=1\) is:

The given first-order ordinary differential equation is \(\left(1-x^2\right) \frac{d y}{d x}-x y=1\).

Dividing both sides by \(1- x ^2\), we can get it in the standard form.

\( \Rightarrow \frac{ dy }{ dx }+\left(\frac{- x }{1- x ^2}\right) y =\frac{1}{1- x ^2} \)

\(\therefore P =\frac{- x }{1- x ^2} .\)

Let's calculate \(\int Pdx\).

\(\int P d x=\int \frac{-x}{1-x^2} d x\)

Substituting \(1-x^2=t\), so that \(-2 x d x=d t\), we get:

\(\Rightarrow \int Pdx =\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{1}{ t } dt\)

Using \(\int \frac{1}{x} d x=\log x+C\) and ignoring the constant \(C\), we get:

\(\Rightarrow \int Pdx =\frac{1}{2} \log t\)

Back substituting \(1-x^2=t\), we get:

\( \Rightarrow \int Pdx =\frac{1}{2} \log \left(1- x ^2\right) \)

\( \Rightarrow \int Pdx =\log \sqrt{1- x ^2}\)

Now, the integrating factor will be:

\(F = e ^{\int P dx } \)

\( \Rightarrow F = e ^{\log \sqrt{1- x ^2}} \)

\( \Rightarrow F =\sqrt{1- x ^2} \) which is the required integrating factor.

\( \Rightarrow \int \frac{1+v^2}{v^3} d v=-\int \frac{1}{x} d x \)

\( \Rightarrow-\frac{1}{2 v^2}+\ln v=-\ln x+c \)

\( \Rightarrow-\frac{x^2}{2 y^2}+\ln \left(\frac{y}{x}\right)=\ln x+c\)

Now, \(y(1)=1 \Rightarrow c=-\frac{1}{2}\)

Its given \(y \left( x _0\right)= e\)

\(\Rightarrow x_0=\sqrt{3} e\)
General solution of \(\left(x^2+y^2\right) d x-2 x y d y=0\) is:

\( \left(x^2+y^2\right) d x=2 x y d y \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d y }{d x}=\frac{\left(x^2+y^2\right) }{ 2 x y} \) is homogeneous.

Put \(y=v x\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d y }{d x} = v + x\frac {dv }{dx} \)

\( \Rightarrow v+x \frac{d v}{d x}=\frac{x^2+v^2 x^2}{2 v x^2}=\frac{x^2\left(1+v^2\right)}{2 v x^2} \)

\( \Rightarrow x \frac{d v}{d x}=\frac{1+v^2}{2 v}-v=\frac{1-v^2}{2 v}\)

\( \Rightarrow \frac{2 v}{1-v^2} d v=\frac{1}{x} d x\)

\( \Rightarrow-\log \left(1-v^2\right)=\log x+\log c \)

\( \Rightarrow \log \left[\frac {1 }{\left(1-v^2\right)}\right]=\log x+\log c \)

\( \Rightarrow\left[\frac {1 }{\left(1-v^2\right)}\right]=c x \)

\( \Rightarrow\left[\frac {1 }{\left(1-\frac{y^2 } {x^2}\right)}\right]=c x \)

\( \Rightarrow\left[\frac{x^2 }{\left(x^2-y^2\right)}\right]=c x\)

\(\Rightarrow x^2=c x\left(x^2-y^2\right)\) is the general solution of the differential equation.
Solve the differential equation \(x d y-2 y d x=0\)

\( x d y-2 y d x=0 \)

\( \Rightarrow x d y=2 y d x \)

\( \Rightarrow \frac{d y}{y}=2 \frac{d x}{x}\)

Integrating both sides, we get

\( \Rightarrow \int \frac{ dy }{ y }=2 \int \frac{ dx }{ x } \)

\( \Rightarrow \ln y =2 \ln x +\ln c \)

\(\Rightarrow \ln y =\ln x ^2+\ln c \)

\( \Rightarrow \ln y -\ln x ^2=\ln c \)

\( \Rightarrow \ln \frac{ y }{ x ^2}=\ln c \)

\(\therefore y = x ^2 c\)
Find general solution of \(x^4 d y-y^4 d x=0\)

\(x^4 d y-y^4 d x=0\)

\(\Rightarrow x^4 d y=y^4 d x \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d y}{y^4}=\frac{d x}{x^4}\)

Integrating both sides, we get

\( \Rightarrow \int \frac{d y}{y^4}=\int \frac{d x}{x^4}\)

\(\Rightarrow \int y^{-4} d y=\int x^{-4} d x \)

\( \Rightarrow \frac{y^{-3}}{-3}=\frac{x^{-3}}{-3}+c\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{y^3}=\frac{1}{x^3}-3 c\)

Consider the inequations 2x + y > 3, x + 2y > 6 and x, y > 0. Which one of the following points lies in the common region?

Converting the inequations to equations, we obtain:

\(2 x+y=3, x+2 y=6, x=0, y=0 .\)

For \(2 x+y=3\)

Putting \(x=0,0+y=3 \Rightarrow y=3\)

Putting \(y=0,2 x+0=3 \Rightarrow x= \frac{3}{2}\)

This line meets the \(x\)-axis at \((32,0)\left(\frac{3}{2}, 0\right)\) and the \(y\)-axis at \((0,3)\). Draw a line through these points.

We see that the origin \((0,0)\) does not satisfy the inequation \(2 x+y>3\)

Therefore, the region that does not contain the origin is the solution of the inequality \(2 x+y>3\)

For \(x+2 y=6\)

Putting \(x=0,0+2 y=6 \Rightarrow y=3\)

Putting \(y=0, x+0=6 \Rightarrow x=6\)

This line meets the \(x\)-axis at \((6,0)\) and the \(y\)-axis at \((0,3)\). Draw a line through these points.

We see that the origin \((0,0)\) does not satisfy the inequation \(x\) \(+2 y>6\)

Therefore, the region that does not contain the origin is the solution of the inequality \(x+2 y>6\)


The solution to the inequalities is the intersection of the 2x + y > 3, x + 2y > 6 and x, y > 0. Thus, the shaded region represents the solution set of the given set of inequalities.

Now solving 2x + y = 3 and x + 2y = 6, we get the point P(0, 3).

Now, Putting (3, 5) in 2x + y > 3,

2(3) + 5 > 3 ⇒ 11 > 3 which is true.

Again, putting (3, 5) in x + 2y > 6,

3 + 2(5) > 6 ⇒ 13 > 6 which is true.

∴ (3, 5) lies in the common region.

Have no solution for positive x and y
Have solution for positive x and y

1. \(3 x-y \geq 3\)
2. \(4 x-4 y>4\)
When analyzing these inequalities, we see that both involve linear expressions of \(x\) and \(y\).
For the first inequality, \(3 x-y \geq 3\), if we solve for \(y\), we get \(y \leq 3 x-3\). This represents a halfplane below the line \(3 x-y=3\).
For the second inequality, \(4 x-4 y>4\), if we solve for \(y\), we get \(x-y=1\)
Now, when we plot these lines and shade the appropriate regions:
1. The line \(3 x-y=3\) and its corresponding half-plane below it.
2. The line \(x-y=1\) and its corresponding half-plane below it.
We find that the feasible region (the overlapping region satisfying both inequalities) exists in the area where both shaded regions overlap. This feasible region extends infinitely for positive values of \(x\) and \(y\). Therefore, the correct answer is: Have solution for positive \(x\) and \(y\).
The point which does not lie in the half plane 2x + 3y -12 < 0 is:

1. For point \((2,3)\) :
\(2(2)+3(3)-12=4+9-12=1>0\)
Therefore, the point \((2,3)\) lies in the half plane.
2. For point \((1,2)\) :
\(2(1)+3(2)-12=2+6-12=-4<0\)
Therefore, the point \((1,2)\) does not lie in the half plane.
3. For point \((-3,2)\) :
\(2(-3)+3(2)-12=-6+6-12=-12<0\)
Therefore, the point \((-3,2)\) lies in the half plane.
4. For point \((2,1)\) :
\(2(2)+3(1)-12=4+3-12=-5<0\)
Therefore, the point \((2,1)\) lies in the half plane.
Thus, the correct answer is \((1,2)\).

Minimize Z = 3x + 5y subject to

\(
\begin{array}{l}

2 x+3 y=12 \Rightarrow \frac{x}{6}+\frac{y}{4}=1 \ldots \text { (i) } \\
-x+y=3 \Rightarrow \frac{x}{-3}+\frac{y}{3}=1 \ldots . \text { (ii) } \\
x=4 \ldots \text { (iii) } \\
y=3 \ldots \text { (iv) }
\end{array}
\)
The graph of inequalities are

Therefore feasible region is ABCDA
Solving (iii) and (iv) we get B = (4, 3)
Solving (ii) and (iii) we get C = (4, 7)

Solving (i) and (ii) we get D = (\(\frac{3}{5}, \frac{18}{5}\))
Now, Z = 3x + 5y

Z(4, 3) = 12 + 15 = 27

The area bounded by the curve \(y=x^4-2 x^3+x^2+3\), the axis of abscissas and two ordinates corresponding to the points of minimum of the function \(y(x)\) is:

Given curve is

\(y = x ^4-2 x ^3+ x ^2+3 \)

\(\therefore \frac{ dy }{ dx }=4 x ^3-6 x ^2+2 x \)

\(\frac{ d ^2 y }{d x ^2}=12 x ^2-12 x +2\)

For maxima and minima \(\frac{ dy }{ dx }=0\)

\(\therefore 4 x ^3-6 x ^2+2 x =0 \)

\(\Rightarrow 2 x \left(2 x ^2-3 x +1\right)=0 \)

\(\therefore x =0, \frac{1}{2}, 1 \)

\(\therefore\left[\frac{ d ^2 y }{ dx ^2}\right]_{ x =0}=2\left(6 x ^2-6 x +1\right) \)

\(\therefore\left[\frac{ d ^2 y }{ dx ^2}\right]_{ x =0}=2,\left[\frac{ d ^2 y }{ dx ^2}\right]_{ x =\frac{1}{2}}=-1\) and \(\left[\frac{ d ^2 y }{ dx ^2}\right]_{ x =1}=2\)

\(\therefore\) Points of minimum are \(x =0\) and \(x =1\)

\(\therefore\) Required Area \(=\int_0^1\left( x ^4-2 x ^3+ x ^2+3\right) dx\)

\(=\left[\frac{x^5}{5}-\frac{2 x^4}{4}+\frac{x^2}{2}+3 x\right]_0^1 \)

\(=\frac{1}{5}-\frac{2}{4}+\frac{1}{3}+3 \)

The area of the region bounded by \(y^2=2 x+1\) and \(x-y-\) \(1=0\) is:

\(y^2=2 x+1 \) and \( x-y=1 \)

\(y^2=2 x+1 \)

\(\Rightarrow y^2=2(1+y)+1 \)

\(\Rightarrow y^2-2 y-3=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow y^2-3 y+y-3=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow(y-3)(y+1)=0 \)

\(\therefore y=3\) or \(-1 \)

\(x=4 \) or  0

\(\therefore\) the curves \(y ^2=2 x +1 \& x - y =1\) intersect at \((4,3) \&(0,-1)\) and we have find the area enclosed by the curves \(y ^2=2 x +1 \& x - y =1\). From the graph above, it is the shaded region which we have to find

\(\therefore\) area enclosed by the graph is \(A=\int_{-1}^3\left\{(y+1)-\frac{1}{2}\left(y^2-1\right)\right\} d y\)

\(=\int_{-1}^3\left\{y+1-\frac{y^2}{2}+\frac{1}{2}\right\} d y \)

\(=\int_{-1}^3\left\{y-\frac{y^2}{2}+\frac{3}{2}\right\} d y=\left\{\frac{y^2}{2}-\frac{y^3}{6}+\frac{3 y}{2}\right\}_{-1}^3=\frac{16}{3} \) sq units.

\(\frac{=4 \sqrt{3}+16 \pi}{3}\)

\(\Rightarrow A_2=16 \pi-\frac{4 \sqrt{3}+16 \pi}{3}=\frac{32 \pi-4 \sqrt{3}}{3} \)

If the area of the region bounded by the curves, \(y=x^2, y=\frac{1}{x}\) and the lines \(y=0\) and \(x=t(t>1)\) is 1 sq. unit, then \(t\) is equal to?

Area bounded by the curves is the region \(ABCD\).

\(=\left[\frac{ x ^3}{3}\right]_0^1+[\ln ( x )]_1^{ t } \)

It is given that area enclosed is 1.

For the given curve: \(y=2 x-x^{2}\), when \(x\) increases at the rate of 3 units/sec, then how the slope of curve changes?

Rate of change of '\(x\)' is given by \(\frac{d x}{d t}\)

Given that, \(y=2 x-x^{2}\) and \(\frac{d x}{d t}=3\) units\(/\)sec

Then, the slope of the curve, \(\frac{d y}{d x}=2-2 x=m\)

\(\frac{ dm }{ dt }=0 - 2 \times \frac{ dx }{ dt }\)

\(=-2(3)=-6\) units per second

Thus, the slope of the curve is decreasing at the rate of 6 units per second when \(x\) is increasing at the rate of 3 units per second.
The interval in which the function \(f(x)=2 x^{3}-15 x^{2}+36 x+12\) is increasing in:

If \(f^{\prime}(x) \geq 0\) at each point in an interval, then the function is said to be increasing.

Given, \(f(x)=2 x^{3}-15 x^{2}+36 x+12\)

Differentiating, we get:

\(f^{\prime}(x)=6 x^{2}-30 x+36\)

\(f' ( x )\) is increasing function:

\(f^{\prime}(x) \geq 0\)

\(=6 x^{2}-30 x+36 \geq 0\)

\(=x^{2}-5 x+6 \geq 0\)

\(=(x-2)(x-3) \geq 0\)

Thus, \(x \in(-\infty, 2] \cup[3, \infty)\)

The interval in which the function \(f (x)=2 x^{3}-15 x^{2}+36 x+10\) is increasing in \((-\infty, 2] \cup\) \([3, \infty)\)

Given:

\(f(x)=X^{5}-20 X^{3}+240 X\)

Differentiate w.r.t \(x\),

\(f^{\prime}(x)=5 X^{4}-60 X^{2}+240=X^{4}-12 X^{2}+48\)

For checking whether the function is Monotonically increasing or decreasing put \(X_{1}=-1\)

\(f^{\prime}\left(X_{1}\right)=(-1)^{4}-12(-1)^{2}+48=1-12+48=37\)

Now, put \(X_{2}=0\)

\(f^{\prime}\left(X_{2}\right)=0-0+48=48\)

Therefore, \(f^{\prime}\left(X_{1}\right) \leq f^{\prime}\left(X_{2}\right)\)

From the above condition we can assume that given function is Monotonically increasing everywhere.
If \(f ( x )\) is an increasing function and \(g ( x )\) is a decreasing function such that \(\operatorname{gof}( x )\) is defined, then gof \((x)\) will be:

Given: \(f(x)\) is an increasing function and \(g(x)\) is a decreasing function

If \(f^{\prime}(x)>0\) then the function is said to be increasing.

If \(f ^{\prime}( x )<0\) then the function is said to be decreasing.

\(\therefore f ^{\prime}( x )>0\) and \(g ^{\prime}( x )<0\)

Let, \(h(x)=\operatorname{gof}(x)=g(f(x))\)

Differentiating with respect to \(x\), we get

\(h^{\prime}(x)=g^{\prime}(f(x)) \times f^{\prime}(x)\)

We know, \(f^{\prime}(x)>0\) and \(g^{\prime}(x)<0\)

Therefore, \(h^{\prime}(x)=(\)Negative\()\times(\)Positive\()=\) Negative

\(\therefore h ^{\prime}( x )<0\)

So, \(\operatorname{gof}( x )\) is decreasing function.
If the line \(y=4 x+c\) is a tangent to the circle \(x^{2}+y^{2}=9\) then find the value possible values of \(c\)?

Given: Equation of line is \(y=4 x+c\) and the line is tangent to the circle \(x^{2}+y^{2}=9\) Here, we have to find the value of \(c\).

As we know that, if the line \(y=m x+c\) is a tangent to the circle \(x^{2}+y^{2}=a^{2}\) then \(c^{2}=\) \(a^{2}\left(1+m^{2}\right)\)

By comparing the given equation of line and circle with \(y = m x + c\) and \(x ^{2}+ y ^{2}=\) \(a ^{2}\) respectively, we get:

\(m =4, a ^{2}=9\)

\(\because m =4\)

\(\Rightarrow m ^{2}=16\)

\(\because c ^{2}= a ^{2}\left(1+ m ^{2}\right)\)

By substituting \(m ^{2}=16\) and \(a ^{2}=9\) in the above equation we get,

\(\Rightarrow c^{2}=9 \times(1+16)=9 \times 17\)

\(\Rightarrow c=\pm 3 \sqrt{17}\)

Let, small charge in \(x\) be \(\Delta x\) and the corresponding change in \(y\) is \(\Delta y\).

Therefore, \(\Delta y =\frac{ dy }{ dx } \Delta x\)

We have to find an approximate value of \((1.04)^{\frac{1}{4}}\)

Let, \(x+\Delta x=1.04=1+0.04\)

Therefore, \(x=1\) and \(\Delta x=0.04\)

Differentiating with respect to \(x\), we get

\(\frac{ dy }{ dx }=\frac{1}{4} x ^{-\frac{3}{4}}\)

At \(x=1\)

\(\left[\frac{ dy }{ dx }\right]_{ x =1}=\frac{1}{4}\) and \(y =1^{\frac{1}{4}}=1\)

As we know \(\Delta y=\frac{d y}{d x} \Delta x\)

So, \(\Delta y =\frac{1}{4} \times 0.04=0.01\)

Therefore, approximate value of \((1.04)^{\frac{1}{4}}=y+\Delta y=1+0.01=1.01\)

The surface area of Sphere \((A)=4 \pi r^{2}\)

\(A=4 \pi r^{2}\)

Differentiating with respect to \(r\), we get:

\(\frac{ d S }{ dr }=8 \pi r\)

\(\Rightarrow dS =8 mr \cdot dr\)

\(\Rightarrow dS =8 \pi \cdot 6 \cdot(0.02)\)

\(\Rightarrow dS =0.96\) square meters

At \(x=243\)

\(\left[\frac{ dy }{ dx }\right]_{ x =243}=\frac{1}{405}\) and \(y =(243)^{\frac{1}{5}}=3\)

Amongst all the pairs of positive numbers with sum 24, find those whose product is maximum?

Let, the pairs of positive numbers with sum 24 be: \(x\) and \(24-x\).

Then, let \(f ( x )\) denotes the product of such pairs

i.e., \(f(x)=x \times(24-x)=24 x-x^{2}\)

Here we have to find that pair of number for which \(f ( x )\) is maximum.

First we have to find \(f ^{\prime}( x )\)

\(f^{\prime}(x)=24-2 x\)

Now let's find the roots of the equation \(f^{\prime}(x)=0\)

\(2 x=24\)

\(\Rightarrow x=12\)

Now let's find out \(f^{\prime \prime}(x)\) i.e., \(\frac{d^{2}(f(x))}{d x^{2}}\)

\(f^{\prime \prime}(x)=-2\)

Now evaluate the value of \(f ^{\prime \prime}( x )\) at \(x =12\)

\(f^{\prime \prime}(12)=-2<0\)

As we know that according to second derivative test if \(f^{\prime \prime}(c)<0\) then \(x=c\) is a point of maxima

So, \(x=12\) is a point of maxima

So, when \(x=12\) then \(24-x=12\)

Thus, the required numbers are 12 and 12
It is given that at \(x=2\), the function \(x^{3}-12 x^{2}+k x-8\) attains its maximum value, on the interval \([0,3]\). Find the value of \(k\).

Following steps to finding maxima and minima using derivatives.

Find the derivative of the function. Set the derivative equal to 0 and solve. This gives the values of the maximum and minimum points. Now we have to find the second derivative.

\(f'(x)\) is less than 0 then the given function is said to be maxima

If \(f'(x)\) Is greater than 0 then the function is said to be minima

Let, \(f(x)=x^{3}-12 x^{2}+k x-8\)

Differentiating with respect to \(x\), we get:

\(f^{\prime}(x)=3 x^{2}-24 x+k\)

It is given that function attains its maximum value of the interval \([0,3]\) at \(x=2\)

\(\therefore f^{\prime}(2)=0\)

\(3 \times 2^{2}-(24 \times 2)+k=0\)

\(\therefore k=36\)
The maximum value of \(\sin \left(x+\frac{\pi}{6}\right)+\cos \left(x+\frac{\pi}{6}\right)\) in the interval \(\left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)\) is attained at

Given: Let \(f(x)=\frac{\operatorname{ln} x}{x}\)

Differentiating both sides, we get:

\(f ^{\prime}( x )=\frac{ d }{ dx }\left(\frac{\operatorname{ln} x }{ x }\right)\)

\(=\frac{\frac{1}{x}( x )-1(\ln x )}{ x ^{2}}\)

\(\Rightarrow f ^{\prime}( x )=\frac{1-\ln x }{ x ^{2}}\)

\(f ^{\prime \prime}( x )=\frac{ d }{ dx }\left( f ^{\prime}( x )\right)\)

\(=\frac{ d }{ dx }\left(\frac{1-\ln x }{ x ^{2}}\right)\)

\(=\frac{ x ^{2} \frac{d}{d x}(1-\ln x )-(1-\ln x ) \frac{ d }{d x}\left( x ^{2}\right)}{\left( x ^{2}\right)^{2}}\)

\(=\frac{ x ^{2}\left(-\frac{1}{x}\right)-(1-\ln x )(2 x )}{ x ^{4}}\)

\(=\frac{- x -2 x +2 x (\ln x )}{ x ^{4}}\)

\(=\frac{ x (-3+2(\ln x ))}{ x ^{4}}\)

\(\Rightarrow f ^{\prime \prime}( x )=\frac{-(3-2 \ln x )}{ x ^{3}}\)

To find the value of \(x\),

\(f ^{\prime}( x )=0\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1-ln x }{ x ^{2}}=0\)

\(\Rightarrow 1-\ln x =0\)

\(\Rightarrow \ln x =1\)

\(\Rightarrow x = e ^{1}= e \quad\left(\ln _{ a } b = c \Rightarrow b = a ^{ c }\right)\)

Now, at \(x=e\),

\(f ^{\prime \prime}( e )=\frac{-(3-2 \ln e )}{ e ^{3}}\)

\(=\frac{-3+2}{ e ^{3}}\)

\(=\frac{-1}{ e ^{3}}<0\)

At \(x=e\), maximum value of \(f(x)\) obtain

\(\therefore f ( x = e )=\frac{\operatorname{ln} x }{ x }\)

\(=\frac{\ln e }{ e }\)

\(=\frac{1}{ e } \quad(\because \ln e =1)\)
The maximum and minimum values of the function |cos 2x + 7| are:

Minimum and maximum value of cos x is -1 and 1

-1 ≤ cos x ≤ 1

So, the minimum and maximum value of cos 2x is -1 and 1

-1 ≤ cos 2x ≤ 1

Maximum value of  |cos 2x + 7|

Here, cos 2x = 1

|1+7| = |8| = 8

Minimum value of  |cos 2x + 7|

Here, cos 2x = -1

|(−1)+7| = |6| = 6

Maximum value = 8, Minimum value = 6
Find the minimum value of \(3 x^{4}-8 x^{3}+12 x^{2}-48 x+1\) on the interval \([1,4]\) and \(x \in R\)?

Let, \(f(x)=3 x^{4}-8 x^{3}+12 x^{2}-48 x+1\) be a function defined on the interval \([1,4]\)

First we have to find \(f^{\prime}(x)\)

\(f^{\prime}(x)=12 x^{3}-24 x^{2}+24 x-48\)

Now let's find the roots of the equation \(f^{\prime}(x)=0\)

\(12 x^{3}-24 x^{2}+24 x-48=0\)

\(\Rightarrow 12 \cdot\left(x^{3}-2 x^{2}+2 x-4\right)=0\)

\(\Rightarrow 12 \cdot\left(x^{2}+2\right) \cdot(x-2)=0\)

\(\Rightarrow x-2=0 \quad \quad \quad\left[\because\left(x^{2}+2\right) \neq 0\right.\) as we are dealing with real valued functions]

\(\Rightarrow x =2\)

Now let's find out \(f^{\prime \prime}(x)\) i.e., \(\frac{d^{2}(f(x))}{d x^{2}}\)

\( f^{\prime \prime}(x)=36 x^{2}-48 x+24\)

Now evaluate the value of \(f^{\prime \prime}(x)\) at \(x=2\), we get:

\(f^{\prime \prime}(2)=72>0\)

As we know that according to second derivative test if \(f^{\prime \prime}(c)>0\) then \(x=c\) is a point of local minima

So, \(x=2\) is a point of local minima

So \(f(2)=-63\)

Let's calculate \(f (0)\) and \(f (3)\)

\(f (0)=1 \text { and } f (3)=-8\)

As we know that if a function is defined in the closed interval \([a, b]\) then the minimum value of \(f ( x )\) on \([ a , b ]\) is the smallest of \(m , f ( a )\) and \(f ( b )\).

So, the minimum value of the given function on the interval \([0,3]\) is \(-63\).
What is the maximum value of \(\sin 2 x \cdot \cos 2x\)?

Let, \(f(x)=\sin 2 x \cdot \cos 2 x\)

\(\Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)=2 \cos ^{2} 2 x-2 \sin ^{2} 2 x\)

\(\Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)=2 \cdot\left(\cos ^{2} 2 x-\sin ^{2} 2 x\right)\)

As we know that, \(\cos 2 x=\cos ^{2} x-\sin ^{2} x\)

\(f^{\prime}(x)=2 \cos 4 x\)

If \(f^{\prime}(x)=0\) then \(2 \cos 4 x=0\)

\(\Rightarrow x=\frac{\pi}{8}\)

\(\Rightarrow f^{\prime \prime}(x)=-8 \sin 4 x\)

\(\Rightarrow f^{\prime \prime}(x)=-8<0\)

So, \(x=\frac{\pi}{8}\) is the point of maxima.

So, the maximum value of \(f(x)=\sin 2 x \cdot \cos 2 x\) is given by \(f\left(\frac{\pi}{8}\right)=\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right) \cdot \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\) \(=\frac{1}{2}\)

We have to find an approximate value of \((1.04)^{1 / 4}\)

Therefore, \(x=1\) and \(\Delta x=0.04\)

Differentiating with respect to \(x\), we get

\(\Rightarrow \frac{ dy }{ dx }=\frac{1}{4} x ^{-3 / 4}\)

At \(x=1\)

Therefore, approximate value of \((1.04)^{1 / 4}=y+\Delta y=1+0.01=1.01\)
If the radius of a sphere is measured as \(4 m\) with an error of \(0.01 m\), then find the approximate error in calculating its volume.

Given: Radius of a sphere \(=4 m\) and \(\Delta r=0.01 m\)

Now, the volume of the sphere is given by,

\(V =\frac{4}{3} \pi r ^3\)

Differentiating with respect to \(r\), we get

\(\Rightarrow \frac{ dV }{ dr }=\frac{4 \pi}{3} \times 3 r ^2=4 \pi r ^2\)

Now,

The approximate error in the volume of sphere \(=\Delta V =\left(\frac{ dV }{ dr }\right) \Delta r\)

\( \therefore \Delta V =4 \pi r ^2 \times \Delta r \)

\( \Rightarrow \Delta V =4 \pi \times 4^2 \times 0.01=0.64 \pi m ^3\)

Hence, the approximate error in the volume of a sphere is \(0.64 \pi m ^3\)

What will be the average rate of change of the function \([y=\) \(\left.16-x^2\right]\) between \(x=3\) and \(x=4\) ?

Let, \(y = f ( x )=16- x ^2\)

If \(x\) changes from 3 to 4 , then, \(\delta x=4-3=1\)

Again \(f(4)=16-4^2=0\)

And \(f(3)=16-3^2=7\)

Therefore, \(\delta y=f(4)-f(3)=0-7=-7\)

Hence, the average rate of change of the function between \(x\) \(=3\) and \(x=4\) is:

\(\frac{\delta y }{ \delta x}=\frac{-7 }{ 1}=-7\).

\(\tan ^{-1} \frac{x}{y}-\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{x-y}{x+y}\right)=\tan ^{-1}\left[\frac{\frac{x}{y}-\frac{x-y}{x+y}}{1+\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)\left(\frac{x-y}{x+y}\right)}\right]\)

If A = {x ∈ R: x2 = 2} and B = {y ∈ R: y2 – 5y + 6 = 0}. Find the total number of relations that can be defined from A to B?

Given: A = {x ∈ R: x2 = 2} and B = {y ∈ R: y2 – 5y + 6 = 0}

\(x^2-2=0\)     .....(Given)

\(\Rightarrow x=\pm \sqrt{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow A=\{\sqrt{2},-\sqrt{2}\}\)

\(\therefore n(A)=2\)

\(y^2-5 y+6=0\)     .....(Given)

\(\Rightarrow y^2-3 y-2 y+6=0\)

\(\Rightarrow(y-3)(y-2)=0\)

\(\Rightarrow y=2,3\)

\(\Rightarrow B=\{2,3\}\)

\(\therefore n(B)=2\)

∵ n(A × B) = n(A) × n(B) ⇒ n(A × B) = 2 × 2 = 4

As we know that, any relation defined from A to B is a subset of the cartesian product, A × B.

∴ The total no. of relations which can be defined from A to B = The no. of subsets of A × B.

⇒ The total no. of relations which can be defined from A to B = 24 = 16

If A and B are the domain and range respectively for the relation R such that R = {(5, 3), (6, 4), (7, 5)} then which of the following option is true?

Domain of a Relation: Let R be a relation from set A to set B. Then, the set of all first components of the ordered pair belonging to relation R forms the domain of the relation R i.e Domain (R) = {a: (a, b) ∈ R}.

Range of a Relation: Let R be a relation from set A to set B. Then, the set of all second components of the ordered pair belonging to relation R forms the range of the relation R i.e Range (R) = {b: (a, b) ∈ R}.

Given: A and B are the domain and range respectively for the relation R such that R = {(5, 3), (6, 4), (7, 5)}

As we know that, Domain (R) = {a: (a, b) ∈ R}

⇒ A = {5, 6, 7}

We also know that Range (R) = {b: (a, b) ∈ R}

⇒ B = {3, 4, 5}
If A = {9, 10, 11, 12, 13} and f: A → N is a function where N is the set of natural numbers such that f(n) = the highest prime factor of n then find the range of f?

Domain:

  • Let f : A → B be a function, then the set A is called as the domain of the function f.

Co-domain:

  • Let f : A → B be a function, then the set B is called as the co-domain of the function f.

Range:

  • Let f : A → B, then the range of the function f consists of those elements in B which have at least one preimage in A. It is denoted as f (A) i.e f (A) = {b ∈ B | f (a) = b for some a A}

Note: Range is the subset of the codomain of f.

Given: A = {9, 10, 11, 12, 13} and f: A → N is a function where N is the set of natural numbers such that f(n) = the highest prime factor of n

We know that, the prime factorization of: 9 = 32, 10 = 2 × 5, 11 = 11 × 1, 12 = 22 × 3 and 13 = 13 × 1

According to the definition of the function f we have,

⇒ f(9) = 3, f(10) = 5, f(11) = 11, f(12) = 3, f(13) = 13

As we know that, if f : A → B, then the range of the function f consists of those elements in B which have at least one preimage in A. It is denoted as f (A) i.e f (A) = {b ∈ B | f (a) = b for some a A}

⇒ Range of f = {3, 5, 11, 13}
If A = {1, 2, 3}, B = {4, 5, 6} and C = {7, 8}. Which one among the following relation is correct?

If A, B and C are three sets, we have

  • A × (B  ∪ C) = (A × B) ∪ (A × C)
  • A × (B ∩ C) = (A × B) ∩ (A × C)
  • A × (B - C) = (A × B) - (A × C)

Option (A): A × (B – C) = (A – B) × (A – C).

As we know that, for any three sets A, B and C we have A × (B - C) = (A × B) - (A × C)

Here, A × (B – C) = (A – B) × (A – C) ≠ (A × B) - (A × C)

So, option (A) is wrong.

Option (B): A × (B – C) = (A × B) – (A × C)

As we know that, for any three sets A, B and C we have A × (B - C) = (A × B) - (A × C)

Here, A × (B – C) = (A × B) - (A × C)

So, option (B) is correct.

Option (C): A × (B ∪ C) = (A ∪ B) × (A ∪ C)

As we know that, A × (B ∪ C) = (A × B) ∪ (A × C)

Here, A × (B ∪ C) = (A ∪ B) × (A ∪ C) ≠ (A × B) ∪ (A × C)

So, option (C) is not correct.
If A = {2, 4, 5}, B = {5, 9, 11} and R is the relation from A to B such that a R b ⇔ b = 2a + 1 then the inverse relation of R is:

Inverse Relation:

Let R be a relation form A to B. Then the inverse relation, denote by R-1, from the set B to A, is defined as, R-1 = {(b, a) : (a, b) ∈ R}.

Calculation:

Given: A = {2, 4, 5}, B = {5, 9, 11} and R is the relation from A to B such that a R b ⇔ b = 2a + 1.

So, when a = 2 ⇒ b = 2a + 1 = 5 ∈ B ⇒ (2, 5) ∈ R

When a = 4 then b = 2a + 1 = 9 ∈ B ⇒ (4, 9) ∈ R

When a = 5 then b = 2a + 1 = 11 ∈ B ⇒ (5, 11) ∈ R

⇒ R = {(2, 5), (4, 9), (5, 11)}

As we know that if R is a relation form A to B. Then the inverse relation, denote by R-1, from the set B to A, is defined as, R-1 = {(b, a) : (a, b) ∈ R}.

⇒ R-1 = {(5, 2), (9, 4), (11, 5)}

A relation R on a non-empty set A is an equivalence relation, if it is:

Illustrating the definition of equivalence relation,

A relation \(R\) defined on a set \(A\) is said to be an equivalence relation if and only if \(R\) is,

  • Reflexive - \(R\) is reflexive if \((a, a) \in R\) for all \(a \in A\)
  • Symmetric - \(R\) is symmetric if and only if \((a, b) \in R \Rightarrow(b, a) \in R\) for all \(a, b \in A\)
  • Transitive - \(R\) is transitive if and only if \((a, b) \in R\) and \((b, c) \in R \Rightarrow(a, c) \in R\) for all \(a, b, c \in A\)

For Example:

Consider a relation "\(=\)" is an equivalence relation on a set of numbers \(A\).

So, for all elements \(a, b, c \in A\), we have,

It is reflexive because \(a=a\) for all \(a \in A\)

It is symmetric because \(a=b \Rightarrow b=a\) for all \(a, b \in A\)

It is transitive because \(a=b, b=c \Rightarrow a=c\) for all \(a, b, c \in A\)

\(\Rightarrow 3\left(3 y-y^{\prime}\right)+y-3 y^{\prime}+y^{\prime \prime}=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow 9 y-3 y^{\prime}+y-3 y^{\prime}+y^{\prime \prime}=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow y^{\prime \prime}-6 y^{\prime}+10 y=0\)

The differential form of the equation

\(y=a e^{-2 x}+b e^{2 x}\)

Given equation is \(y=a e^{-2 x}+b e^{2 x}\)

There are two constants \(a\) and \(b\) so differentiate two times

Differentiating w.r.t \(x\), we get

\(y^{\prime}=-2 a e^{-2 x}+2 b e^{2 x}\)

Differentiating again w.r.t \(x\)

\(y^{\prime \prime}=4 a e^{-2 x}+4 b e^{2 x} \)

\(y^{\prime \prime}=4\left(a e^{-2 x}+b e^{2 x}\right) \)

\(y^{\prime \prime}=4 y \)

\(y^{\prime \prime}-4 y=0\)
The differential form of the equation \(y ^2+( x - b )^2= c\)

Given equation is \(y ^2+( x - b )^2= c\)

There are two constants \(b\) and \(c\) so differentiate two times

Differentiating w.r.t \(x\)

\(2 y \frac{d y}{d x}+2(x-b)=0 \)

\(y \frac{d y}{d x}=b-x\)

Differentiating again w.r.t \(x\)

\(\left(\frac{d y}{d x}\right)^2+y \frac{d^2 y}{d x^2}=-1 \)

\(y \frac{d^2 y}{d x^2}+\left(\frac{d y}{d x}\right)^2+1=0\)

Given equation is \(y^2=\sin (a x+b)\)

There are two constants \(a\) and \(b\) so differentiate two times

Differentiation with respect to \(x\). we get

\(2 yy' = a \cos ( ax + b )\)

Squaring both sides, we get

\(4\left(y y^{\prime}\right)^2=a^2 \cos ^2(a x+b) \)

\(4\left(y y^{\prime}\right)^2=a^2\left(1-\sin ^2(a x+b)\right) \)

\(4\left(y y^{\prime}\right)^2=a^2\left(1-y^4\right) \)

\(a^2=\frac{4\left(y y^{\prime}\right)^2}{\left(1-y^4\right)}\)

Now, \(2 y^{\prime}=a \cos (a x+b)\)

Again, Differentiation with respect to \(x\). we get

\(2\left(y^{\prime}\right)^2+2 y y^{\prime \prime}=-a^2 \sin (a x+b)\)

Put the value of \(a^2\), we get

\(2\left(y^{\prime}\right)^2+2 y y^{\prime \prime}=-\frac{4\left(y y^{\prime}\right)^2}{\left(1-y^4\right)} y^2 \)

\(y^4\left(y^{\prime}\right)^2+y^5 y^{\prime \prime}-\left(y^{\prime}\right)^2-y y^{\prime \prime}-2 y^4\left(y^{\prime}\right)^2=0 \)

\(\left(y^5-y\right) y^{\prime \prime}-\left(y^{\prime}\right)^2-y^4\left(y^{\prime}\right)^2=0\)
Form the differential equation of the following equation \(y=e^{4 x}(a+b x)\).

Given equation is \(y=e^{4 x}(a+b x)\)

There are 2 constants \(a\) and \(b\) so differentiate 2 times

\(\Rightarrow y^{\prime}=4 a e^{4 x}+b e^{4 x}+4 b x e^{4 x} \)

\(\Rightarrow y^{\prime}=4 e^{4 x}(a+b x)+b e^{4 x} \)

\(\Rightarrow y^{\prime}=4 y+b e^{4 x} \)

\(\Rightarrow b e^{4 x}=y^{\prime}-4 y\)

Differentiating one more time

\(\Rightarrow 4 b e^{4 x}=y^{\prime \prime}-4 y^{\prime} \)

\(\Rightarrow 4\left(y^{\prime}-4 y\right)=y^{\prime \prime}-4 y^{\prime} \)

\(\Rightarrow y^{\prime \prime}-8 y^{\prime}+16 y=0\)
The differential equation of all lines passing through the origin is:

The general equation of all lines passing through the origin is \(y=m x\), where \(m\) is a constant. Differentiating this equation with respect to \(x\), we get:

\(\frac{ d }{ dx }( y )=\frac{ d }{ dx }( mx ) \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{ dy }{ dx }= m =\frac{ y }{ x }\)
The differential equation of all parabolas whose axis is \(y\)-axis is:

Equation of parabola with \(y\)-axis and vertex \((0, k)\) is
\((x-0)^2=4 a(y-k) \text {. }\)
Now,
Given, equation of parabola with \(y\)-axis and vertex \((0, k)\) is
\((x-0)^2=4 a(y-k) \)
\(\Rightarrow x^2=4 a y-4 a k\)
Taking derivative on both side, we get
\(\Rightarrow 2 x =4 a \frac{ dy }{ dx } \)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{ x } \frac{ dy }{ dx }=\frac{1}{2 a }\)
Again taking derivative on both side, we get.
\(\Rightarrow \frac{d}{d x}\left(\frac{1}{x} \frac{d y}{d x}\right)=\frac{d}{d x}\left(\frac{1}{2 a}\right) \)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{x} \frac{d^2 y}{d x^2}+\frac{d y}{d x}\left(\frac{-1}{x^2}\right)=0 \)
\(\Rightarrow x \cdot \frac{d^2 y}{d x^2}-\frac{d y}{d x}=0\)
Hence, the differential equation of all parabolas whose axis is y-axis is \(x \cdot \frac{d^2 y}{d x^2}-\frac{d y}{d x}=0\)
The differential equation of system of concentric circles with centre \((1,2)\) is:

Given: circles with centre \((1,2)\)

Let the radius of the circle be \(r\)

Now, the equation of a circle is \((x-1)^2+(y-2)^2=r^2\)

Differentiating with respect to \(x\), we get

\(\Rightarrow 2(x-1)+2(y-2) \frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{d^2}{d x} \)

\(\Rightarrow 2(x-1)+2(y-2) \frac{d y}{d x}=0 \quad\left(\because \frac{d(\text { constant })}{d x}=0\right) \)

\(\therefore(x-1)+(y-2) \frac{d y}{d x}=0\)
Which one of the following differential equation represents the family of straight lines which are at unit distance from the origin?

Let the straight lines be of the form: \(y=m x+c\)...(i)

\(\Rightarrow y - mx - c =0\)

Given: straight lines which are at unit distance from the origin

\(1=\left|\frac{0-0- c }{\sqrt{1+ m ^2}}\right| \)

\(\Rightarrow c =\sqrt{1+ m ^2}\)

Replacing \(c\) in eqn (i)

\(y = mx +\sqrt{1+ m ^2}\)...(ii)

On differentiating with respect to \(x\), we get

\(\frac{ dy }{ dx }= m\)

Replacing \(m\) in eqn (ii)

\(y=\frac{d y}{d x} x+\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{d y}{d x}\right)^2} \)

\(\Rightarrow y-\frac{d y}{d x} x=\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{d y}{d x}\right)^2} \)

\(\Rightarrow\left(y-\frac{d y}{d x} x\right)^2=1+\left(\frac{d y}{d x}\right)^2\)
What is the differential equation corresponding to \(y^2-2 a y+x^2=a^2\) by eliminating \(a\) ? Where \(p =\frac{ dy }{ dx }\)

Given: \(y^2-2 a y+x^2=a^2\)...(1)

Differentiating both sides w.r.t \(x\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{2 y d y}{d x}-2 a \frac{d y}{d x}+2 x=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow 2 p y-2 a p+2 x=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow p y+x=a p \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{p y+x}{p}=a\)

Put \(a =\frac{ py + x }{ p }\) in equation (1)

\(y^2-2 y\left(\frac{p y+x}{p}\right)+x^2=\left(\frac{p y+x}{p}\right)^2 \)

\(\Rightarrow p^2 y^2-2 p y(p y+x)+p^2 x^2=\left(p^2 y^2+x^2+2 p x y\right) \)

\(\Rightarrow-2 p^2 y^2-2 p x y+p^2 x^2-x^2-2 p x y=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow\left(x^2-2 y^2\right) p^2-4 p x y-x^2=0\)
The differential equation representing the family of curves \(y=a \sin (\lambda x+\alpha)\) is:

Given:

\(y=a \sin (\lambda x+\alpha)\)........(1)

Now differentiating both sides, we get

\(\Rightarrow \frac{ dy }{ dx }=\frac{ ad \sin (\lambda x +\alpha)}{ d (\lambda x +\alpha)} \times \frac{ d (\lambda x +\alpha)}{ dx } \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{ dy }{ dx }= a \lambda \cos (\lambda x +\alpha)\)

Again differentiating both sides, we get

\(\Rightarrow \frac{ d ^2 y }{ dx ^2}=- a \lambda^2 \sin (\lambda x + a )\)

From equation \(1^{\text {st }}\),

\(\Rightarrow \frac{ d ^2 y }{ dx ^2}=-\lambda^2 y \)

\(\therefore \frac{ d ^2 y }{ dx ^2}+\lambda^2 y =0\)
What is the number of arbitrary constants in the particular solution of differential equation of third order?

As we know that in particular solution no arbitrary constants are there.

So, the number of arbitrary constants in the particular solution of the differential equation of third order \(=0\)
Which among the following statement is NOT correct regarding differential equations?
The particular solution is obtained by giving particular values to arbitrary constants in the General solution
Power of the highest order derivative in a differential equation is called the order of the differential equation
To form a differential equation, we have to differentiate the given equation \(n\) times to get \(n\) more equations

In differential equations, General solution consists of \(n\) arbitrary constants.

The particular solution is obtained by giving particular values to arbitrary constants in the General solution.

To form a differential equation, we have to differentiate the given equation \(n\) times to get \(n\) more equations and then by using all these equations we can eliminate the constants to get the required differential equation.

Power of the highest order derivative in a differential equation is called Degree of the differential equation whereas the order of the highest derivative in a differential equation is called the order of the differential equation.

\(\cos ^{-1}\left(4 x^3-3 x\right)\)

\(=\cos ^{-1}\left(4 \cos ^3 \theta-3 \cos \theta\right)\)

Find the domain of the inverse trigonometric function

\(\sin ^{-1}\left(2 x \sqrt{1-x^2}\right)\)

\(\sin ^{-1}\left(2 x \sqrt{1-x^2}\right)\)

The domain of inverse \(\sin\) function, \(\sin x\) is \(\in[-1,1]\) Domain of the function is calculated as follows:

\(\sin ^{-1}\left(2 x \sqrt{1-x^2}\right)\)

\(-1 \leq 2 x \sqrt{1-x^2} \leq 1\)

\(-\frac{1}{2} \leq x \sqrt{1-x^2} \leq \frac{1}{2}\)

\(x^2\left(1-x^2\right) \leq \frac{1}{4}\)

\(\text { Let, } x^2=t\)

\(t(1-t) \leq \frac{1}{4}\)

\(t-t^2-\frac{1}{4} \leq 0\)

\(\left(t-\frac{1}{2}\right)^2 \leq 0\)

\(t \leq \frac{1}{2}=x^2 \leq \frac{1}{2}=x \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\)

\(x \in\left[-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}, \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right]\)
If \(\sin ^{-1} x+\sin ^{-1} y=\frac{5 \pi}{6}\), then what is the value of \(\cos ^{-1} x+\cos ^{-1} y\)?

\(\sin ^{-1} x+\sin ^{-1} y=\frac{5 \pi}{6}\)

We know that:

\(\sin ^{-1} x+\cos ^{-1} x=\frac{\pi}{2}\)

\(\tan ^{-1} x+\cot ^{-1} x=\frac{\pi}{2}\)

Let, \(\cos ^{-1} x+\cos ^{-1} y=a\)

Adding the two equation we get,

\(\left(\sin ^{-1} x+\cos ^{-1} x\right)+\left(\sin ^{-1} y+\cos ^{-1} y\right)=\frac{5 \pi}{6}+a\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\pi}{2}+\frac{\pi}{2}=\frac{5 \pi}{6}+a\)

\(\Rightarrow \pi-\frac{5 \pi}{6}=a \Rightarrow a=\frac{\pi}{6}\)

So, \(\cos ^{-1} x+\cos ^{-1} y=\frac{\pi}{6}\)

\(\operatorname{cosec} \theta=2\)

Find the value of \(x\) for the equation \(2 \tan ^{-1}(\cos x)=\tan ^{-1}(2 \operatorname{cosec} x) ?\)

Given,

\(2 \tan ^{-1}(\cos x)=\tan ^{-1}(2 \operatorname{cosec} x)\)

As we know that, \(2 \tan ^{-1} x=\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{2 x}{1-x^{2}}\right),-1 \leq x \leq 1\)

\(2 \tan ^{-1}(\cos x)=\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{2 \cos x}{1-\cos ^{2} x}\right)\)

As we know that, \(\sin ^{2} x+\cos ^{2} x=1\)

\(\Rightarrow 2 \tan ^{-1}(\cos x)=\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{2 \cos x}{\sin ^{2} x}\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{2 \cos x}{\sin ^{2} x}\right)=\tan ^{-1}(2 \operatorname{cosec} x)=\tan ^{-1}(\frac{2}{\sin x})\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{2 \cos x}{\sin ^{2} x}=\frac{2}{\sin x} \)

\(\Rightarrow \cos x \sin x-\sin ^{2} x=0\)

\(\Rightarrow \sin x(\cos x-\sin x)=0\)

\(\Rightarrow \sin x=0\) or \( \cos x-\sin x=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow x=0\) or \(\frac{\pi}{4}\)

As we can see that for \(x=0\) the given equation does not exist Thus, \(x=\frac{\pi }{4}\) is the only solution for the given equation.

\(=2 \theta \quad\left(\because \cos ^{-1} \cos x=x\right)\)

\(=2 \tan ^{-1} x \quad(\because x=\tan \theta)\)

Given,

\(\sec (\tan ^{-1} \frac{\mathrm{y}}{2})\)

Let's say that \(\tan ^{-1} \frac{y}{2}=\theta\), where \(\theta \in\left[-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}\right]\).

\(\Rightarrow \tan \theta=\frac{y}{2}\)

Squaring both sides, we get

\(\Rightarrow \tan ^{2} \theta=\frac{y^{2}}{4}\)

\(\Rightarrow 1+\tan ^{2} \theta=1+\frac{y^{2}}{4}\)

\(\Rightarrow \sec ^{2} \theta =\frac{4+y^{2}}{4} \) \(\quad\quad(\because1+\tan ^{2}=\sec ^{2} \theta)\)

\(\Rightarrow \sec ^{2}\theta=\frac{y^{2}+4}{4}\)

\(\Rightarrow \sec \theta=\frac{\sqrt{y^{2}+4}}{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \sec \left(\tan ^{-1} \frac{y}{2}\right)=\frac{\sqrt{y^{2}+4}}{2}\)

Given,

\(\sec ^{-1}\left[\frac{x^{2}+1}{x^{2}-1}\right]\)

Put \(x=\tan \theta\)

\(=\sec ^{-1}\left[\frac{\tan ^{2} \theta+1}{\tan ^{2} \theta-1}\right]\)

\(=\sec ^{-1}\left[\frac{\frac{\operatorname{ate}^{2} \theta+\operatorname{cas}^{2} \theta}{\cos ^{2} \theta}}{\frac{\sin ^{2} \theta-\cos ^{2} \theta}{\cos ^{2} \theta}}\right]\)

\(=\sec ^{-1}\left[\frac{\sin ^{2} \theta+\cos ^{2} \theta}{\sin ^{2} \theta-\cos ^{2} \theta}\right]\)

\(=\sec ^{-1}\left[\frac{1}{-\left(\cos ^{2} \theta-\sin ^{2} \theta\right)}\right] \quad\left(\because \sin ^{2} \theta+\cos ^{2} \theta=1\right)\)

\(=\sec ^{-1}\left[\frac{1}{-\cos 2 \theta}\right] \quad\left(\because \cos ^{2} \theta-\sin ^{2} \theta=\cos 2 \theta\right)\)

\(=\sec ^{-1}[-\sec 2 \theta] \quad\left(\because \frac{1}{\cos \theta}=\sec \theta\right)\)

\(=\pi-\sec ^{-1}[\sec 2 \theta] \quad\left(\because \sec ^{-1}(-\theta)=\pi-\sec ^{-1} \theta\right)\)

\(=\pi-2 \theta \quad\left(\because \sec ^{-1}(\sec \theta)=\theta\right)\)

Replace \(\theta\) in terms of \(\mathrm{x}_{1}\)

\(x=\tan \theta \Rightarrow \theta=\tan ^{-1} x \)

\(=\pi-2 \tan ^{-1} x\)

\(=\pi-2\left(\frac{ { \pi}}{2}-\cot ^{-1} x\right)\left(\because \tan ^{-1} x+\cot ^{-1} x=\frac{\pi}{2}\right) \)

\(=\pi-\pi+2 \cot ^{-1} x \)

\(=2 \cot ^{-1} x\)

Given,

\(x=\tan ^{-1}(\frac{1}{5})\)

\(\tan x=\frac{1}{5}\)

As we know that, \(\sin 2 \theta=\frac{2 \tan \theta}{1+\tan ^{2} \theta}\)

\(\therefore \sin 2 x=\frac{2 \tan x}{1+\tan ^{2} x}\)

\(=\frac{2 \times \frac{1}{5}}{1+\left(\frac{1}{5}\right)^{2}} \)

\(=\frac{\left(\frac{2}{5}\right)}{\frac{25+1}{25}} \)

\(=\frac{2}{5} \times \frac{25}{26}=\frac{10}{26}\)

\(=\frac{5}{13}\)

\(\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{1-x}{1+x}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \tan ^{-1} x\)

\(\Rightarrow 2 \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{1-x}{1+(1 \times x)}\right)=\tan ^{-1} x\)

\(\Rightarrow 2\left[\tan ^{-1} 1-\tan ^{-1} x\right]=\tan ^{-1} x\)

\(\Rightarrow 2\left(\tan ^{-1} 1\right)=3 \tan ^{-1} x\)

\(\Rightarrow 2 \times \frac{\pi}{4}=3 \tan ^{-1} x\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\pi}{6}=\tan ^{-1} x\)

\(\Rightarrow x=\tan \frac{\pi}{6}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\)

\(\sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{2 a}{1+a^{2}}\right)+\sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{2 b}{1+b^{2}}\right)=2 \tan ^{-1} x\)

Let \(\mathrm{a}=\tan \mathrm{y}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{b}=\tan \mathrm{y}_{2}\)

Therefore, the given equation becomes:

\(\sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{2 a}{1+a^{2}}\right)+\sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{2 b}{1+b^{2}}\right)=2 \tan ^{-1} x\)

\(\sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{2\left(\tan y_{1}\right)}{1+\left(\tan y_{1}\right)^{2}}\right)+\sin ^{-1}\)\(\left(\frac{2\left(\tan y_{2}\right)}{1+\left(\tan y_{2}\right)^{2}}\right)=2 \tan ^{-1} x \)

\(\sin ^{-1}\left(\sin 2 y_{1}\right)+\sin ^{-1}\left(\sin 2 y_{2}\right)=2 \tan ^{-1} x\)

\(2 y_{1}+2 y_{2}=2 \tan ^{-1} x \)

\(y_{1}+y_{2}=\tan ^{-1} x \)

\(\tan \left(y_{1}+y_{2}\right)=x \)

\(\frac{\tan y_{1}+\tan y_{2}}{1-\tan y_{1} \tan y_{2}}=x\)\(\quad\quad(\because \tan (x+y) =\frac{\tan x+\tan y}{1-\tan x \tan y})\)

\(\therefore x=\frac{a+b}{1-a b}\)

Given

According to Pythagoras triplet, \(\sin \alpha=\frac{4}{5}\)

Now, \(\tan \alpha=\frac{\sin \alpha}{\cos \alpha}=\frac{\frac{4}{5}}{\frac{3}{5}}=\frac{4}{3}\)

We know that, \(\tan (\alpha-\beta)=\frac{\tan \alpha-\tan \beta}{1+\tan \alpha-\tan \beta}\)

\(\Rightarrow \tan (\alpha-\beta)=\frac{\frac{4}{3}-\frac{1}{3}}{1+\frac{4}{9}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \tan (\alpha-\beta)=\frac{\frac{3}{3}}{\frac{13}{9}} \)

\(\Rightarrow \tan (\alpha-\beta)=\frac{9}{13} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\sin (\alpha-\beta)}{\cos (\alpha-\beta)}=\frac{9}{13}\)

According to options,

Now, \(\sin (\alpha-\beta)=\frac{9}{5 \sqrt{10}}\)

\(\therefore \alpha-\beta=\sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{9}{5 \sqrt{10}}\right)\)

Here, \(\alpha-\beta=\sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{9}{5 \sqrt{10}}\right)\)
If tan-1 2, tan-1 3 are two angles of a triangle, then what is the third angle?

Consider the third angle as A

Given, tan-1 2, tan-1 3 are two angles of a triangle.

We know that,

\(\tan ^{-1} {a}+\tan ^{-1} {b}=\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{{a}+{b}}{1-{ab}}\right)\)

Consider

\(\tan ^{-1} 2+\tan ^{-1} 3=\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{2+3}{1-2.3}\right)\)

\(\tan ^{-1} 2+\tan ^{-1} 3=\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{5}{-5}\right)\)

\(\tan ^{-1} 2+\tan ^{-1} 3=\tan ^{-1}(-1)\)

\(\tan ^{-1} 2+\tan ^{-1} 3=\frac{3 \pi}{4}\)

Now, the sum of angles of the triangle is 180º i..e π.

\(\tan ^{-1} 2+\tan ^{-1} 3+{A}=\pi\)

\(\frac{3 \pi}{4}+A=\pi\)

\({A}=\frac{\pi}{4}\)

If tan-1 2, tan-1 3 are two angles of a triangle, then the third angle is \(\frac{\pi}{4}\).
One of the roots of \(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}x+a & b & c \\ a & x+b & c \\ a & b & x+c\end{array}\right|=0\) is

Given that,

\(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}x+a & b & c \\ a & x+b & c \\ a & b & x+c\end{array}\right|=0\)

Applying \(C_1 \rightarrow C_1+C_2+C_3\) we get

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow\left|\begin{array}{ccc}x+a+b+c & b & c \\ x+a+b+c & x+b & c \\ x+a+b+c & b & x+c\end{array}\right|=0 \\ & \Rightarrow(x+a+b+c)\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & b & c \\ 1 & x+b & c \\ 1 & b & x+c\end{array}\right|=0\end{aligned}\)

Applying \(R_2 \rightarrow R_2-R_1\) and \(R_3 \rightarrow R_3-R_1\)we get

\(\Rightarrow(x+a+b+c)\left|\begin{array}{lll}1 & b & c \\ 0 & x & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & x\end{array}\right|=0\)

Now, expanding along \(C_1\)

\(\begin{aligned} & (x+a+b+c) \cdot 1 \cdot\left(x^2\right)=0 \\ & \Rightarrow x^2 \cdot(x+a+b+c)=0 \\ & \Rightarrow x=0 \text { or } x=-(a+b+c)\end{aligned}\)

Let \(\Delta=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\sec ^2 x & \tan ^2 x & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 1 \\ 10 & 8 & 2\end{array}\right|\)

Apply \(C_1 \rightarrow C_1-C_2\)

\(\Delta=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\sec ^2 x-\tan ^2 x & \tan ^2 x & 1 \\ 2-1 & 1 & 1 \\ 10-8 & 8 & 2\end{array}\right|\)

\(\Delta=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & \tan ^2 x & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 8 & 2\end{array}\right| \quad\left(\because \sec ^2 x-\tan ^2 x=1\right)\)

As we know,

If two rows or two columns of a determinant are identical the value of the determinant is zero.

Here \(C_1\) and \(C_3\) are identical.

So, \(\Delta=0\)
What is the value of the determinant \(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}i & i^2 & i^3 \\ i^4 & i^6 & i^8 \\ i^9 & i^{12} & i^{15}\end{array}\right|\) where \(i=\sqrt{-1}\)

Let determinant \(\mathrm{D}\) is  \(\left|\begin{array}{ccc}i & i^2 & i^3 \\ i^4 & i^6 & i^8 \\ i^9 & i^{12} & i^{15}\end{array}\right|\)

Since, we have,

\(i=\sqrt{-1}\)

\(\therefore i^2=-1, i^3=-i, i^4=1, i^6=-1, i^8=1, i^9=i, i^{12}=1\),

and \(i^{15}=-i\)

\(\mathrm{D}\) \(=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}i & -1 & -i \\ 1 & -1 & 1 \\ i & 1 & -i\end{array}\right|\)

\(=i(i-1)+1(-i-i)-i(1+i)\)

\(=i^2-i-2 i-i-i^2\)

\(=-4 i\)

The factorized form of the following determinant is:
